revision.text:
{{short description|Libyan businessman and politician}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Ahmed Omar Maiteeq | image = Ahmed Maiteeq.jpg | office = [[Presidential Council (Libya)|Vice Chairman of the Presidential Council of Libya]] | president = [[Fayez al-Sarraj]] | term_start = 30 March 2016 | term_end = | predecessor = Imhemed Shaib & Ahmed Huma {{small|(Deputy Presidents of
the House of Representatives)}} | successor = | office1 = [[Cabinet of Libya|Deputy Prime Minister of Libya]] | primeminister1 = [[Fayez al-Sarraj]] | term_start1 = 5 April 2016{{cite web |url=http://rulers.org/rull.html#libya |title=Countries L |website=''rulers.org'' |access-date=5 April 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160416083419/http://rulers.org/rull.html#libya#libya |archive-date=16 April 2016 |dead-url=no |df=}} | office2 = [[List of heads of government of Libya|Prime Minister of Libya]] | president2 = [[Nouri Abusahmain]] | term_start2 = 25 May 2014 | term_end2 = 9 June 2014 | predecessor2 = [[Abdullah al-Thani]] | successor2 = [[Abdullah al-Thani]] | birth_date = 1972 | birth_place = [[Tripoli]], [[Libya]] | death_date = | death_place = | footnotes = *Maiteeq's term was disputed by [[Abdullah al-Thani]]. }} '''Ahmed Omar Maiteeq''' is a [[Libya]]n businessman and politician, originally from Misrata, who was elected [[Prime Minister of Libya]] in May 2014.{{Cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/libyan-parliament-elects-new-pm-201454135721191517.html |title=Libyan parliament elects new PM |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=4 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521211447/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/libyan-parliament-elects-new-pm-201454135721191517.html |archivedate=21 May 2014 |deadurl=no |accessdate=4 June 2014}} His election as prime minister took place under disputed circumstances. The Justice Ministry decided on 29 May that Maiteeq was not the Prime Minister due to voting procedural issue occurred when the First Deputy of GNC left the session without valid reason. The Libyan Supreme Court was expected to issue a verdict on 5 June 2014 regarding the election of Maiteeq,{{Cite news |url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/06/04/breaking-news-thinni-travels-to-benghazi/ |title=Breaking news: Thinni travels to Benghazi |work=Libya Herald |date=4 June 2014 |accessdate=4 June 2014}} although it indicated on that day that it believed that the appointment of Maiteeq was invalid, the court stated that appeals should be heard and delayed a final ruling until 9 June.{{Cite news |url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/06/06/supreme-court-sees-maetig-appointment-at-illegal-but-postpones-final-decision-until-9-june/ |title=Supreme Court sees Maetig appointment at illegal but postpones final decision until 9 June |work=Libya Herald |date=6 June 2014 |accessdate=6 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606214120/http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/06/06/supreme-court-sees-maetig-appointment-at-illegal-but-postpones-final-decision-until-9-june/#axzz33mfyI2ck#axzz33mfyI2ck |archive-date=6 June 2014 |dead-url=no |df=}} The court ruled on 9 June that Maiteeq appointment was invalid; [[Abdullah al-Thani]] is expected to stay on as prime minister.{{cite news |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/libya-declares-pm-election-unconstitutional-20146981130265348.html |title=Libya PM's election declared unconstitutional |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=9 June 2014 |accessdate=9 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140612020630/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/06/libya-declares-pm-election-unconstitutional-20146981130265348.html |archive-date=12 June 2014 |dead-url=no |df=}} Maiteeq submitted his resignation voluntarily in same day.{{Cite news |url=http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/06/09/maetig-accepts-supreme-court-ruling/ |title=Maetig accepts Supreme Court ruling and resigns |work=Libya Herald |date=9 June 2014 |accessdate=9 June 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140611111449/http://www.libyaherald.com/2014/06/09/maetig-accepts-supreme-court-ruling/#axzz33mfyI2ck#axzz33mfyI2ck |archive-date=11 June 2014 |dead-url=no |df=}} == Early life and education == Maiteeq was born on 1972 in Tripoli, Libya. His father held a number of high offices during the monarchical period prior to the [[Muammar Gaddafi|Gaddafi]] regime. Maiteeq is a cousin to the controversial [[General National Congress|GNC]] representative from [[Misrata]], [[Abdulrahman Asswehly]]. He was also the grandson of the Libyan freedom fighter, [[Ramadan Asswehly]]. He obtained degrees in economy and business management from a university in [[London]].{{cite web |url=http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/News/6168/19/Libya%E2%80%99s-new-prime-minister.aspx |title=Libya's new prime minister |date=8 May 2014 |access-date=30 September 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161003111427/http://weekly.ahram.org.eg/News/6168/19/Libya%E2%80%99s-new-prime-minister.aspx |archive-date=3 October 2016 |dead-url=no |df=}} == 2011 civil war == During the [[Libyan Civil War (2011)|Libyan Civil War]], he took part in the fighting in Misrata and the liberation of Tripoli. He was a member of the Chamber for the Liberation of Tripoli during the conflict and a member of the Tripoli Development and Stability Council after the fall of the regime. == Prime Minister and Deputy Prime Minister == Following Acting Prime Minister [[Abdullah al-Thani]]'s call that he would resign on 13 April for an alleged attack on his family, he was persuaded to stay on till a new leader was elected.{{cite web |url=http://time.com/60814/libya-prime-minister-quits/ |title=Libya PM Quits, Says He Was Targeted in Armed Attack |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] | date=13 April 2014 |accessdate=27 May 2014 |author=Frizell, Sam |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140531080848/http://time.com/60814/libya-prime-minister-quits/ |archive-date=31 May 2014 |dead-url=no |df=}} The first day of voting on 28 April was disrupted by armed men firing in parliament.{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27276153 |title=Libya appoints Ahmed Maitig as new prime minister |publisher=BBC |date=4 May 2014 |accessdate=27 May 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140606095144/http://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-27276153 |archive-date=6 June 2014 |dead-url=no |df=}} In a voting session at the [[General National Congress]] that was described by ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' as "chaotic," Maiteeq was elected, and took the oath, "I swear I will carry out my duties honestly and in devotion." Later MP Fathi al-Majbari told Libyan television station ''[[Al-Ahrar]]'': "There are violations in today's session" and that a certain alteration of the votes had occurred after the session was adjourned."{{cite web |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/confusion-surrounds-libya-pm-election-201454195446967363.html |title=Confusion surrounds Libya PM's election |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=5 May 2014 |accessdate=27 May 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521211535/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/confusion-surrounds-libya-pm-election-201454195446967363.html |archivedate=21 May 2014 |deadurl=no}} Ultimately in the days that followed, the Libyan Supreme Court ruled that the election of Maiteeq had been invalid, and the previous Prime Minister, al-Thani, agreed to return to office. al-Thani, had earlier signed an agreement with those holding the smaller oil export terminals of Hariga and Zueitina, those holding the larger Ras Lanuf and Es Sider terminals refused to recognise Maiteeq. Spokesman Ali Hasi said: "Maiteeq came to power illegally."{{Cite news |date=7 May 2014 |accessdate=27 May 2014 |title=Libyan rebels refuse to deal with new PM |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/libyan-rebels-refuse-deal-with-new-pm-201457104123867408.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140521211310/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2014/05/libyan-rebels-refuse-deal-with-new-pm-201457104123867408.html |archivedate=21 May 2014 |deadurl=no}} Maiteeq identifies as an independent and as not affiliated to any political party or movement.{{Cite news |title=رئيس الوزراء الليبي المكلف: لا أنتمي لأي تيار سياسي لا إسلامي ولا غيره (Libyan Prime Minister-designate: I do not belong to any political movement not an Islamic or any other) |language=Arabic |date=6 May 2014 |accessdate=27 May 2014 |newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm |url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/news/details/441258 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512230823/http://www.almasryalyoum.com/news/details/441258 |archivedate=12 May 2014 |deadurl=no}} In March 2016, he became Deputy Prime minister{{Cite news |url=http://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/world/60393/new_divisions_come_forth_as_rival_parliaments_unite_against_imposed_libya_government |title=New divisions come forth as rival parliaments unite against ‘imposed’ Libya government |work=''MaltaToday.com.mt'' |access-date=12 June 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612184738/https://www.maltatoday.com.mt/news/world/60393/new_divisions_come_forth_as_rival_parliaments_unite_against_imposed_libya_government |archive-date=12 June 2018 |dead-url=no |df=}} and Vice-Chairman of the Presidential Council.{{Cite web |url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201603081452.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=2 April 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160410141600/http://allafrica.com/stories/201603081452.html |archive-date=10 April 2016 |dead-url=no |df=}} In March 2017, he had a meeting in [[Moscow]] with the Special Representative of the [[President of Russia]] for the Middle East and Africa, Mikhail Bogdanov, where they discussed the ongoing [[Second Libyan Civil War|Libyan crisis]] and solutions for resolving the conflict, including the possibility of negotiations between the GNA and the Tobruk-based [[Council of Deputies]].[http://www.mid.ru/ru/foreign_policy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/2664935 О встрече спецпредставителя Президента Российской Федерации по Ближнему Востоку и странам Африки, заместителя Министра иностранных дел России М.Л.Богданова с Вице-премьером Правительства национального согласия Ливии А.Майтигом | On the meeting of Special Representative of the President of the Russian Federation for the Middle East and countries of Africa, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs of Russia M.L. Bogdanov with Vice-Premier of the Government of National Accord of Libya, A. Maiteeq] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303122713/http://www.mid.ru/ru/foreign_policy/news/-/asset_publisher/cKNonkJE02Bw/content/id/2664935 |date=3 March 2017 }}. 2 March 2017. Russian Foreign Ministry.[https://sg.news.yahoo.com/russia-urges-national-dialogue-libya-pm-meeting-180126274.html Russia urges 'national dialogue' at Libya PM meeting] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170302232707/https://sg.news.yahoo.com/russia-urges-national-dialogue-libya-pm-meeting-180126274.html |date=2 March 2017 }}. Yahoo News. Published 2 March 2017. Retrieved 2 March 2017. == Family == He is married and has four children. == See also == * [[Maiteeq Cabinet]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{s-start}} {{s-off}} {{s-bef|before=[[Abdullah al-Thani]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[List of heads of government of Libya|Prime Minister of Libya]] | years=2014}} {{s-aft|after=[[Abdullah al-Thani]]}} {{s-end}} {{LibyaPMs}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Maiteeq, Ahmed Omar}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Libyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Libyan politicians]] [[Category:Prime Ministers of Libya]] [[Category:1972 births]]

page.title: American National Business Hall of Fame

revision.text:
'''Bright Ideas Trust''' (BIT) is a [[registered charity]] founded in 2007 by Richard Morris and former ''[[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]'' winner [[Timothy Campbell (businessman)|Tim Campbell]], established to help disadvantaged people aged 16-30 build their own businesses.
==Target group==
The charity was established to encourage young people from disadvantaged backgrounds to get involved in enterprise.
Bright Ideas Trust provides end-to-end business start-up support, mentoring and access to funding to disadvantaged 16- to 30-year-olds, including those who are not in employment, education or training (NEET). <ref>http://www.brightideastrust.com</ref>
Bright Ideas Trust currently has staff located in London and the North East of England but is able to remotely support young people from across the UK.
==Charitable activities==
Despite being a charity, Bright Ideas Trust does not give away grants but instead helps beneficiaries access start-up finance via start-up loans. <ref>https://www.facebook.com/brightideastrust?fref=ts</ref>
The charity provides bespoke support for young people who want to start their own business. Each young person is matched with a mentor, who works with them during the business planning stage and for at least the first twelve months of the business trading. Mentors are usually experienced entrepreneurs from a wide variety of sectors.
Every 2 months Bright Ideas Trust hosts an informal networking event for young people and people interested in helping them set up in business. Each event includes an interview with a young person the charity has helped, a guest speaker who is usually an established business owner and an expert business panel q&a session.
Bright Ideas Trust also delivers enterprise awareness workshops and events in schools, colleges, universities and other youth organisations to help young people make fully informed decisions regarding their career choice.
Bright Ideas Trust also engages with prisons, youth offending teams, housing associations and other organisations supporting employability projects for young people.
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Business education in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Charities based in London]] [[Category:Organisations based in the City of London]]

revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=November 2014}} [[File:Carsten Henrik Bruun jr.jpg|thumb|Carsten Henrik Bruun (1904)]] '''Carsten Henrik Bruun''' (7 November 1868 – 16 July 1951) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] military officer, sport shooter and businessperson.
He was born in [[Tønsberg]]<ref name=sref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sports-reference.com/olympics/athletes/br/carsten-bruun-2.html|title=Carsten Bruun|publisher=Sports-Reference.com|accessdate=18 December 2010}}</ref> as the second son of ship-owner [[Carsten Henrik Bruun|Carsten Henrik Carstensen Bruun]] (1828–1907) and Maren Sibylle Bull Foyn (1840–1918). He was an older brother of [[Svend Foyn Bruun Sr.|Svend Foyn Bruun]],<ref name=sem>{{cite book|last=Johnsen|first=Oscar Albert|title=Sem og Slagen. En bygdebok|url=http://www-bib.hive.no/tekster/sem_slagen/gaardshistorie1/46.html|accessdate=18 December 2010|volume=1|year=1945|publisher=Sem og Slagen bygdebokkomite|location=Sem|chapter=Aker|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724180543/http://www-bib.hive.no/tekster/sem_slagen/gaardshistorie1/46.html#|archive-date=24 July 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and as such an uncle of [[Svend Foyn Bruun, Jr.|Svend Foyn Bruun Jr]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|year=1972|volume=1|edition=3rd|title=Bruun, Svend Foyn (jr)|encyclopedia=Gyldendals store konversasjonsleksikon|editor1=Bull, Francis|editor1-link=Francis Bull|editor2=Tandberg, Erik |editor3=Eskeland, Arnold |publisher=Gyldendal|location=Oslo|language=Norwegian|page=2543}}</ref> On the paternal side he was a great-grandnephew of founding father [[Henrik Carstensen]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nsd.uib.no/polsys/index.cfm?urlname=storting&lan=&MenuItem=N1_1&ChildItem=&State=collapse&UttakNr=33&person=10450|title=Svend Foyn Bruun|publisher=Norwegian Social Science Data Services (NSD)|language=Norwegian|accessdate=18 December 2010}}</ref> and on the maternal side he was a grandson of [[Laurentius Føyn|Laurentius Føyn Jr]], who was a brother of noted whaler [[Svend Foyn]].<ref name=sem/>
He was married to Esther Larsen (1872–1940).<ref name=sem/>
He was a Major in the Infantry of the [[Norwegian Army]], and served as chief executive officer of Elektricitets-Aktieselskabet AEG,<ref name=sem/> the Norwegian branch of German company [[AEG|Allgemeine Elektricitäts-Gesellschaft]] (AEG).<ref name=snl>{{cite encyclopedia|year=2007|title=AEG|encyclopedia=[[Store norske leksikon]]|editor=Henriksen, Petter|publisher=Kunnskapsforlaget|location=Oslo|url=http://www.snl.no/AEG|language=Norwegian|accessdate=18 December 2010}}</ref> He also had a sporting career. At the age of 43 he participated in the [[Shooting at the 1912 Summer Olympics – Men's trap|men's trap]] competition at the [[Shooting at the 1912 Summer Olympics|1912 Summer Olympics]]. He finished in joint 27th place.<ref name=sref/> For his achievements he was decorated as a Knight of the [[Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav]].<ref name=sem/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Bruun, Carsten Henrik}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1951 deaths]] [[Category:People from Tønsberg]] [[Category:Norwegian Army personnel]] [[Category:Norwegian businesspeople]] [[Category:Norwegian male sport shooters]] [[Category:Shooters at the 1912 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic shooters of Norway]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Christopher Lawford | image = Christopherlawford.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = Lawford in September 2008 | birth_name = Christopher Kennedy Lawford | birth_date = {{Birth date|1955|03|29|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Santa Monica, California]], U.S. | death_date = {{death date and age|2018|09|04|1955|03|29|mf=yes}} | death_place = [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]], Canada | resting_place = | monuments = | residence = | nationality = American | other_names = Chris Lawford | alma_mater = [[Tufts University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|B.A.]])
{{nowrap|[[Boston College Law School]] ([[Juris Doctor|J.D.]])}}
[[Harvard University]] | occupation = Author, actor, activist | years_active = 1988–2018 | spouse = {{marriage|Jeannie Olsson|1984|2000|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Lana Antonova|2005|2009|reason=divorced}}
{{marriage|Mercedes Miller|2014|2016|reason=divorced}} | children = 3 | parents = [[Peter Lawford]]
[[Patricia Kennedy Lawford]] | relatives = See [[Kennedy family]] | awards = | website = {{URL|christopherkennedylawford.com/}} }} '''Christopher Kennedy "Chris" Lawford''' (March 29, 1955 – September 4, 2018){{cite web |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/05/obituaries/christopher-kennedy-lawford-dead.html |title=Christopher Kennedy Lawford, Actor and Author Who Battled Addiction, Dies at 63 |first= Amie|last= Tsang|date=September 5, 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=September 6, 2018}} was an American author, actor, and activist. He was a member of the prominent [[Kennedy family]], and son of actor [[Peter Lawford]]. ==Early life and education== Lawford was born in [[Santa Monica, California]], at [[Saint John's Health Center]].{{cite web|last=Lawford|first=Christopher Kennedy|title='Symptoms of Withdrawal: Memoir of Snapshots and Redemption'|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2005/10/30/books/chapters/1030-1st-lawford.html|publisher=nytimes.com|date=October 30, 2005}} He was the eldest child and only son of actor [[Peter Lawford]] (1923–1984) and socialite [[Patricia Kennedy Lawford|Patricia "Pat" Kennedy Lawford]] (1924–2006). His three younger sisters are Sydney McKelvy (born 1956), Victoria Lawford (born 1958), and Robin Lawford (born 1961). Lawford was a nephew of President [[John F. Kennedy]] and former cousin-in-law of actor/politician [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] (appearing in two of his films, including ''[[Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines]]''). Peter and Patricia Lawford divorced in 1966 after which Patricia raised the children in New York City.{{cite web|last=Cohen|first=Charles E.|title=Peter Lawford Was His Dad, Pat Kennedy His Mom, and Heroin His Undoing—Now Christopher Lawford Is Back on Track|url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20114648,00.html|publisher=people.com|date=March 11, 1991}} Before his parents' divorce, Lawford attended St. Martin of Tours Elementary School in Los Angeles.{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Gemma|title=Breaking the Curse of the Kennedys|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/ipad/breaking-the-curse-of-the-kennedys/story-fn6bqvxz-1226287785732|publisher=adelaidenow.com.au|date=March 2, 2012}} Upon moving to New York City with his mother, he attended the [[Middlesex School]] in [[Concord, Massachusetts]]. He later earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Tufts University]] in 1977. In 1983, he earned a [[Juris Doctor|J.D.]] from [[Boston College Law School]], and a master's certificate in Clinical Psychology from [[Harvard University]], where he gained an academic appointment as a Lecturer in Psychiatry.{{cite web|last=Thomas|first=Bob|title=Lawford tells tale of privilege and pain|url=http://m.spokesman.com/stories/2005/oct/08/lawford-tells-tale-of-privilege-and-pain/|publisher=spokesman.com|date=October 8, 2005}} ===Drug and legal issues=== Lawford began taking drugs while attending the Middlesex School. By the late 1970s, he had developed a serious drug abuse problem. He briefly attended [[Fordham University School of Law]], but dropped out after several months due to his dependency on heroin. He later contracted [[Hepatitis C]] due to his drug abuse. In 1980, he was arrested in [[Aspen, Colorado]] for impersonating a doctor in order to get prescription medication. The charges were later dropped when Lawford completed his probation. In April 1984, Lawford's cousin [[David A. Kennedy|David Kennedy]], who also battled substance abuse issues and with whom Lawford had a close relationship, died of a drug overdose. David's death prompted Lawford to seek professional help for his issues. He attended addiction behavior classes at the [[Cambridge Hospital]] and became sober. ==Career== ===Acting=== In 1988, Lawford decided to pursue a career in acting. He spent over fifteen years in the film and television business as an actor, lawyer, executive, and producer. As an independent producer Lawford arranged financing for and produced films including ''[[Kiss Me Guido]]'' (in 1997) which he also appeared as 'Dakota',{{cite web |title=Kiss Me, Guido, TV Guide |url=https://www.tvguide.com/movies/kiss-guido/cast/132510/ |website=TVGuide.com |accessdate=11 November 2018 |language=en}} & ''Drunks''; both films were selections in the [[Sundance Film Festival]]. Lawford's acting credits include ''Eavesdrop'', ''[[Slipstream (2007 film)|Slipstream]]'', ''[[The World's Fastest Indian]]'', ''[[Terminator 3]]'', ''[[Blankman]]'', ''[[The Doors (film)|The Doors]]'', ''[[The Russia House (film)|The Russia House]]'', ''[[Thirteen Days (film)|Thirteen Days]]'', and many others. His credits also include a three-year tenure on the soap opera ''[[All My Children]]'' and a role on ''[[General Hospital]]''. ===Writing=== In September 2005, [[HarperCollins]] published Lawford's memoir ''Symptoms of Withdrawal: A Memoir of Snapshots and Redemption'' (William Morrow 2005, {{ISBN|0-06-073248-2}}), which immediately became a New York Times Bestseller. In 2009, he released ''Moments of Clarity: Voices from the Front Lines of Addiction and Recovery'', a series of essays by public figures, athletes and entertainers who have struggled with addiction to drugs and alcohol. Almost every interviewee sought help from a [[twelve-step program]] such as [[Alcoholics Anonymous]], [[Narcotics Anonymous]] or another spiritually based means of support for recovery. In his own life, Lawford battled a drug and alcohol addiction for much of his early life.[http://www.cadca.org/pressreleases/detail/actor-author-and-activist-christopher-kennedy-lawford-joins-cadcas-board-direct "Actor, Author, and Activist Christopher Kennedy Lawford Joins CADCA's Board of Directors"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101229231243/http://www.cadca.org/pressreleases/detail/actor-author-and-activist-christopher-kennedy-lawford-joins-cadcas-board-direct |date=December 29, 2010 }} Press release, Community Anti-Drug Coalitions of America (Alexandria, VA), February 26, 2010. Retrieved 2010-05-10. ===Activism=== Lawford worked extensively in politics, government and the non-profit sector holding executive staff positions with The [[Democratic National Committee]], The Community Action for Legal Services Agency and in the Washington office of Senator [[Ted Kennedy|Edward M. Kennedy]]. He has held staff positions on numerous national, state and local political campaigns, as well as with The [[Joseph P. Kennedy Jr. Foundation]], [[Special Olympics]] and The [[Center on Addiction and Substance Abuse]] at [[Columbia University]]. He was later a Public Advocacy Consultant for Caron Treatment Centers, and was appointed by Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger to serve on the California Department of Public Health Advisory Board. ==Insight on Castro== Lawford told Australian interviewers that he had been trying to make a film about the 1962 [[Cuban missile crisis]] from [[Cuba]]'s perspective but that he had been stymied by the U.S. embargo. Lawford told the Australian newspaper that he sat next to Cuban leader [[Fidel Castro]] in [[Havana]] during a 2001 screening of ''[[Thirteen Days (film)|Thirteen Days]]'', a film about the missile crisis. "It was incredible. I went there and sat next to the guy my uncles were trying to kill. But President Castro believes if President Kennedy had lived, the embargo would have been lifted and they would have normalized relations." In a separate interview with ABC, Lawford said Castro "got up at the end of the film and he said, 'You've made a great film, but you've ignored Cuba, now you have to make a film of what was happening here in Cuba during those thirteen days." Lawford said that he had returned to Cuba six times in an effort to do just that "but as you know we have an embargo against Cuba, which is one of the greatest foreign policy tragedies in the history of the United States."Source: News Story from [[IMDB]] news briefings. The Cuban government has not commented on this allegation. ==Personal life== ===Marriages and children=== In November 1984, Lawford married Jeannie Olsson, a sales advertising assistant for ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine.{{cite book|last=Bly|first=Nellie|title=The Kennedy Men: Three Generations of Sex, Scandal and Secrets|year=1996|publisher=Kensington Books|isbn=1-575-66106-3|page=28}} The couple had three children: Christopher Kennedy Lawford Jr., Savannah Rose Lawford, and Matthew LeMoyne Kennedy Lawford. They divorced in 2000. On August 22, 2005, Lawford married Lana Antonova, a Russian actress and entrepreneur, in a small ceremony in Las Vegas, NV. The couple divorced in December 10, 2009. In May 2014, Lawford married Mercedes Miller, a yoga teacher, in Maui, Hawaii.{{cite web |url=http://www.people.com/article/christopher-kennedy-lawford-marries-mercedes-miller |title=Christopher Kennedy Lawford Marries in Hawaii|last=McNeil|first=Liz |publisher=Time Inc.|date=May 27, 2014 |website=People.com |accessdate=August 2, 2014}} ===Religion=== Lawford was raised in the [[Roman Catholic]] faith.{{cite web|last=Sheridan|first=Patricia|title=Patricia Sheridan's Breakfast With ... Christopher Kennedy Lawford|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/life/lifestyle/2009/02/02/Patricia-Sheridan-s-Breakfast-With-Christopher-Kennedy-Lawford/stories/200902020159|publisher=post-gazette.com|date=February 2, 2009}} In a 2009 interview, Lawford claimed that he left the church in 1968 stating:
[...] I left the Catholic Church when I was 13 years old after my [[Assassination of Robert F. Kennedy|Uncle Bobby was assassinated]], saying I would never go back, and I didn't really have a need for God and I didn't really believe in God. He wasn't useful to me. But I had gotten an understanding that there were spiritual people. My grandmother, [[Rose Kennedy]], was a devout Catholic, but she was also a very spiritual person. She walked and meditated every day of her life. Her faith and spirituality got her through enormous trauma. That was not lost on me. My grandmother was this beacon of equilibrium in a world that was crazy. [...]That's [Roman Catholicism] just not something that speaks to me. I have my own tradition. I go to an [[ashram]]. I meditate. I chant. I do all that kind of stuff [...]
===Art sale=== In March 2010, Lawford sold at auction a 1965 [[Pablo Picasso|Picasso]] painting, ''Femme au Grand Chapeau. Buste.'' The painting was estimated to sell at [[Sotheby's]] for between $8 million to $12 million and ended up bringing $8.2 million, or $9.3 million with Sotheby's buyer's commission.[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/05/06/arts/design/06auction.html "A Sober Follow-Up to a Record Auction Night"] by Carol Vogel, ''The New York Times'', May 5, 2010 (May 6, 2010 on p. A24 of National ed.). Retrieved 2010-05-10. ===Death=== On September 5, 2018, Christopher's cousin [[Kerry Kennedy]] announced via her Twitter account that Lawford had died and paid tribute to him.https://twitter.com/KerryKennedyRFK/status/1037353830424424448https://patch.com/california/hollywood/jfk-nephew-actor-christopher-lawford-dies-64 That same day, law enforcement officials in Hollywood, California told TMZ that Lawford suffered a heart attack at a yoga studio in Vancouver, British Columbia,http://www.vancourier.com/author-actor-kennedy-scion-christopher-lawford-dead-at-63-1.23422469 the previous evening and later died.https://people.com/politics/john-f-kennedy-nephew-christopher-lawford-dies-63/https://fox8.com/2018/09/05/reports-christopher-kennedy-lawford-dead-at-63/ An autopsy is being performed to the determine the exact cause of death, which is believed to have been natural causes.{{Citation needed|date=September 2018}} ==Awards and honors== Lawford supported Women in Recovery, Inc., a non-profit organization offering a live-in, [[12-step program]] of rehabilitation for women in need, based in [[Venice, California]]. This charity, which was founded by a longtime resident of Venice, Sister Ada Geraghty, annually honors those who have made a difference in helping women overcome substance abuse problems. Lawford was the 2006 honoree for Women in Recovery at their Gala; past honorees have included [[Jamie Lee Curtis]], [[Angela Lansbury]], and [[Anthony Hopkins]]. ==Filmography== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! class="unsortable" | Notes |- | 1988 | ''The Suicide Club'' | Boyfriend | |- | 1988 | ''[[Mr. North]]'' | Michael Patrick Ennis III | |- | 1988 | ''[[Spellbinder (1988 film)|Spellbinder]]'' | Phil | |- | 1990 | ''[[Impulse (1990 film)|Impulse]]'' | Steve | |- | 1990 | ''[[The Russia House (film)|The Russia House]]'' | Larry | |- | 1991 | ''[[Run (1991 film)|Run]]'' | Martins | |- | 1991 | ''[[The Doors (film)|The Doors]]'' | New York Journalist | |- | 1993 | ''[[Jack the Bear]]'' | Vince Buccini | |- | 1994 | ''[[Blankman]]'' | Mayor Marvin Harris | |- | 1995 | ''[[Drunks (film)|Drunks]]'' | Rich | |- | 1996 | ''The Abduction'' | Dan Solano | |- | 1997 | ''[[Kiss Me, Guido]]'' | Dakota | Executive Producer |- | 1997 | ''Fool's Paradise'' | Sen. Brill | |- | 1998 | ''[[Witness to the Mob]]'' | Prosecutor John Gleeson | |- | 1998 | ''Dead Broke'' | Joshua | |- | 1998 | ''Not Even the Trees'' | | |- | 1998 | ''Ask for Becky Whiteworth'' | | |- | 1999 | ''[[The Confession (1999 film)|The Confession]]'' | D.A. Elliott Cunningham | |- | 1999 | ''[[The Waiting Game (film)|The Waiting Game]]'' | L.A. Director | Credited as Chris Lawford |- | 1999 | ''[[The Sex Monster]]'' | Dave Pembroke | |- | 1999 | ''[[Mary, Mother of Jesus (film)|Mary, Mother of Jesus]]'' | Reuben | |- | 2000 | ''R2PC: Road to Park City'' | Christoper Lawford | |- | 2000 | ''[[Chump Change (film)|Chump Change]]'' | Studio Executive #1 | |- | 2000 | ''[[The 6th Day]]'' | Police Lieutenant | |- | 2000 | ''[[Thirteen Days (film)|Thirteen Days]]'' | Cmdr. [[William Ecker]] | |- | 2001 | ''[[Exit Wounds]]'' | Vice President | Credited as Chris Lawford |- | 2001 | ''Walking Shadow'' | Jimmy Christopholous | |- | 2001 | ''[[Fourplay (film)|Fourplay]]'' | Davis | |- | 2001 | ''Red Zone'' | | |- | 2002 | ''Counterstrike'' | Vice President Chet Ridgeway | |- | 2002 | ''Hitters'' | Cassidey | |- | 2003 | ''[[Terminator 3: Rise of the Machines]]'' | Brewster's Aide | Credited as Chris Lawford |- | 2005 | ''[[The World's Fastest Indian]]'' | Jim Moffet | Credited as Chris Lawford |- | 2007 | ''[[Slipstream (2007 film)|Slipstream]]'' | Lars | |- | 2008 | ''Eavesdrop'' | Claude | |- |} ==See also== * [[Kennedy family#Family tree|Kennedy family tree]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.christopherkennedylawford.com}} *{{IMDb name|id=0492441}} {{Kennedy family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lawford, Christopher Kennedy}} [[Category:1955 births]] [[Category:American film producers]] [[Category:American health and wellness writers]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male soap opera actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:American male non-fiction writers]] [[Category:American memoirists]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:American political activists]] [[Category:Boston College Law School alumni]] [[Category:Fordham University School of Law alumni]] [[Category:Former Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Harvard University alumni]] [[Category:Kennedy family]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:Male actors from Santa Monica, California]] [[Category:Tufts University alumni]] [[Category:Writers from Santa Monica, California]] [[Category:Middlesex School alumni]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Consumer organizations in New Zealand to [[:Category:Consumer organisations in New Zealand]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{COI|date=April 2016}} '''Consumer NZ''', previously known as '''Consumers' Institute of New Zealand''', is an organization that covers a wide range of activities relating to [[consumer protection]] and information. Its work includes comparative tests and surveys of consumer goods and services, research into and advice on financial, food, health, safety, welfare and environmental matters, representation at parliamentary committees and public enquiries and an interest in [[consumer education]] and complaints advisory work.
== History == The Consumers’ Council was established in 1959{{cn|date=July 2013}} ‘to protect and promote the interest of consumers of goods and services’.{{cn|date=July 2013}} In 1963 the name Consumers Institute was adopted{{cn|date=July 2013}} and in 1967 it became a separate government funded entity.{{cn|date=July 2013}} In 1986 the Ministry of [[Consumer protection|Consumer Affairs]] was established and the Consumers Institute lost its special legal protection and government funding.{{cn|date=July 2013}} The Consumers Institute became an incorporated society funded by members’ subscriptions in 1989{{cn|date=July 2013}} and in 2007 the Consumers’ Institute was renamed Consumer NZ.
In 2016 the organisation had over 100,000 members and supporters.
The [[Minister of Consumer Affairs (New Zealand)]] has cited Consumer NZ as a source of guidance for consumers wanting to understand the [[Consumer Guarantees Act (NZ)|Consumer Guarantees Act]].<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.consumeraffairs.govt.nz/legislation-policy/policy-reports-and-papers/disscussion-papers/consumer-law-reform-a-discussion-paper/12.-consumer-guarantees |title=12. Consumer Guarantees - Consumer Affairs |first= |last=|work=consumeraffairs.govt.nz |year=2010 |accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref> With the [[Ministry of Consumer Affairs (New Zealand)]], Consumer NZ manages Powerswitch, which is a project to assist consumers in evaluating the costs of consuming electricity.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.consumeraffairs.govt.nz/news-1/word-of-advice/2011/power-up-with-powerswitch |title=Power up with powerswitch - Consumer Affairs |first= |last= |work=consumeraffairs.govt.nz |date=30 May 2011 |accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ea.govt.nz/consumer/powerswitch/ |title=Powerswitch » Electricity Authority |author=[[Electricity Authority (NZ)]] |work=ea.govt.nz |date=22 October 2010 |accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref>
== Testing == Consumer commissions independent laboratories to carry out product tests.{{cn|date=July 2013}} Consumer does not accept [[free good]]s for testing or sponsorship.{{cn|date=July 2013}} The magazine is completely independent and has no ties with any commercial firm or organisation.{{cn|date=July 2013}} Their membership of [[Consumers International]] means they benefit from an exchange of information with [[Consumer organization|consumer organisations]] around the world.{{cn|date=July 2013}}
The organization does not permit any marketer to use its test results to promote their products.<ref>{{cite news|last=Swann|first=Allan|title=Consumer NZ gives Progressive the hard word|url=http://www.nbr.co.nz/article/consumer-nz-gives-progressive-hard-word-35393|accessdate=15 July 2013|newspaper=[[National Business Review]]|date=18 September 2008}}</ref>
The organization has been criticized for emphasizing shortcomings in [[nursing homes]], with health care workers saying that Consumers NZ demands more from health care services than it is reasonable to expect.<ref>{{cite news|title=Watchdog group under fire over rest home criticism|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=10897509|accessdate=15 July 2013|newspaper=[[The New Zealand Herald]]|date=12 July 2013}}</ref>
== The Board == Consumer NZ is governed by an elected board of seven members who hold office for three years. The current chair is Richard Aston. The deputy chair is [[Sue Kedgley]].<ref name=Board>{{cite web | url=https://www.consumer.org.nz/articles/cb | title=Consumer Board | publisher=Consumer NZ | accessdate=July 10, 2017}}</ref> As part of Consumers’ work on behalf of all NZ consumers, they regularly make submissions to Government and statutory authorities on a wide range of issues affecting consumers.
Consumers' money comes from the sale of publications and subscriptions to ''Consumer'' and consumer.org.nz. When a customer subscribes to Consumer magazine or consumer.org.nz they become a member of Consumer NZ (unless they request otherwise) and have the right to nominate and vote for Board members. The style of the magazine has been critiqued and described as a "distinctive authorial" presentation.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Hannis |first=Grant |title=Visual communication in consumer journalism: The case of Consumer magazine in New Zealand |journal=[[PRism (journal)|PRism]] |year=2010 |volume=3 |issue=4 |url=http://www.prismjournal.org/hannis.html|accessdate=15 July 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://consumer.org.nz/ Official Web Site]
{{Consumers International}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Consumers NZ}} [[Category:Consumer organisations in New Zealand]] [[Category:Members of Consumers International]] [[Category:Consumer rights organizations]]

revision.comment: Added back image with fair use rationale for this article
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = Cupid's Span | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | image = Cupid's Span.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | artist = {{Flatlist| * [[Claes Oldenburg]] * [[Coosje van Bruggen]]}} | catalogue = | year = {{start date|2002}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | type = Sculpture | material = | subject = | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | condition = | city = San Francisco, California, United States | museum = | accession = | coordinates = {{coord|37.79156|-122.39005|format=dms|type:landmark_region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | pushpin_map = United States San Francisco | pushpin_map_caption = Location in San Francisco | map_size = | owner = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Cupid's Span''''' is an outdoor sculpture by married artists [[Claes Oldenburg]] and [[Coosje van Bruggen]], installed along the [[Embarcadero (San Francisco)|Embarcadero]] in [[San Francisco]], California, in the United States. The {{Convert|60|ft|m|adj=on}} sculpture, commissioned by [[Gap (clothing retailer)|GAP]] founders [[Donald Fisher|Donald]] and [[Doris F. Fisher]], depicts a partial bow and piece of an arrow.<ref name=Hoge>{{cite news|last1=Hoge|first1=Patrick|title=S.F. struck by love / Cupid's big bow gets rise out of passers-by|url=http://www.sfgate.com/news/article/S-F-struck-by-love-Cupid-s-big-bow-gets-rise-2751612.php|accessdate=November 19, 2015|work=San Francisco Chronicle|date=November 23, 2002}}</ref>
==Description and history== [[Claes Oldenburg]] and [[Coosje van Bruggen]]'s ''Cupid's Span'', made of fiberglass and steel, was installed in the newly built Rincon Park along the [[Embarcadero (San Francisco)|Embarcadero]] in San Francisco in 2002.<ref name=Hoge/> The piece resembles [[Cupid]]'s bow and arrow, drawn, with the arrow and bow partially implanted in the ground; the artists stated that the piece was inspired by San Francisco's reputation as the home port of Eros, hence the stereotypical bow and arrow of Cupid.<ref>[http://www.oldenburgvanbruggen.com/largescaleprojects/cupidsspan.htm Cupid's Span]. Chronology of Large-Scale Projects by Claes Oldenburg and Coosje van Bruggen. oldenburgvanbruggen.com. August 25, 2009. Retrieved 2012-11-04.</ref> Leydier and Penwarden wrote, "Love's trade-mark weapon naturally evokes the city's permissive and romantic reputation, while formally its taut curve resonates wonderfully with the structure of the famous suspension bridge in the background."<ref>Leydier, Richard; Penwarden, C. (December 2006). "Claes Oldenburg & Coosje van Bruggen: l'envol et la chute / Rise and Fall: Oldenburg & van Bruggen." Art Press no. 329: 28-33. (Art Full Text, H.W. Wilson, EBSCOhost, accessed November 10, 2012).</ref>
==See also== * [[2002 in art]] * [[List of public art by Oldenburg and van Bruggen]] * [[List of public art in San Francisco]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
[[Category:2002 establishments in California]] [[Category:2002 sculptures]] [[Category:Cupid]] [[Category:Financial District, San Francisco]] [[Category:Outdoor sculptures in San Francisco]]

{{Use British English| date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates| date=January 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Dan Adamescu | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Dan Grigore Adamescu | birth_date = {{Birth date|1948|09|20|df=y}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{Death date and age|2017|01|24|1948|09|20|df=y}} | death_place = | nationality = Romanian, German | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | known for = | home_town = | salary = | networth = US$1 billion (2013)<ref name=Forbes/> | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | spouse = Carmen Palade (divorced) | children = 1 son | parents = | relatives = | website = }}
'''Dan Grigore Adamescu''' (20 September 1948 – 24 January 2017) was a [[Romania]]n businessman who was the founder of The Nova Group, and was the second richest Romanian in 2013. In 2016, he was sentenced to four years and four months in jail for bribing judges at his companies' insolvency trials. Adamescu held Romanian and German citizenships.<ref name=EJ>{{cite news| url= http://ejpress.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=56662&catid=14| title= The new Communists: Romania is moving backwards| last=Black | first=Eldad| work=European Jewish Press| date=6 January 2017| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
==Career== [[File:Piata Unirii - Magazinul Unirea - Noaptea.jpg|thumb| 200px| The [[Unirea Shopping Center]], which was owned by Adamescu.]] Born in [[Vaideeni]], [[Vâlcea County]], Adamescu entered business in 1971, after graduating from the [[Bucharest Academy of Economic Studies]].<ref name=evz>{{cite news| url= http://www.evz.ro/dan-grigore-adamescu-biografia-neromantata-a-unui-mogul-de-presa-1.html| title= Dan Grigore Adamescu. Biografia neromanțată a unui mogul de presă | last=Pârvu| first= Mihnea| work=[[Evenimentul Zilei]]| date=24 January 2017| accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref> He spent eleven years working in Germany, and returned to Romania in 1989. He made his wealth in the early 1990s, when Romania was moving from [[communism]] to capitalism.<ref name=BR>{{cite news| url= http://www.business-review.eu/news/romanian-millionaire-dan-adamescu-gets-jail-sentence-for-bribery-106964| title= Romanian millionaire Dan Adamescu gets jail sentence for bribery| work=Business Review| date=27 May 2016| accessdate=27 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=ND>{{cite news| url= http://www.newsday.com/news/world/dan-adamescu-romanian-millionaire-convicted-of-bribery-1.13010559| title= Dan Adamescu, Romanian millionaire convicted of bribery| work=[[Associated Press]]| date=24 January 2017| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> Adamescu was critical of the Romanian Government's anti-corruption policies.<ref name=Forbes>{{cite news| url= https://www.forbes.com/sites/stephenmcgrath/2017/01/25/jailed-romanian-businessman-dies-as-anti-corruption-fight-in-spotlight/#8b49d887f146| title= Jailed Romanian Businessman Dies As Anti-Corruption Fight In Spotlight| last=Macgrath| first= Stephen| work=[[Forbes]]| date=25 January 2017| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref>
In 2013, [[Forbes]] estimated Adamescu's [[net worth]] at US$900 million, making him the second-richest Romanian, after [[Ioan Niculae]]. At the time, he was the majority shareholder of The Nova Group, which owned companies including [[România Liberă]], Astra Insurance, [[ASC Oțelul Galați]], and the [[Unirea Shopping Center]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.viata-libera.ro/sport/48384-otelul-are-al-doilea-cel-mai-bogat-patron-din-liga-i-adamescu-e-pe-locul-doi-in-top-forbes-si-capital| title= Otelul are al doilea cel mai bogat patron din liga i adamescu e pe locul doi in top forbes si capital| last=Savastru| first=Marian| work=[[Viața Liberă]]| date=15 November 2013| accessdate=27 January 2017| language=ro}}</ref> In 2015, Forbes Romania estimated his net worth to be €550 million.<ref name=BR/> In October 2016, Alexander Adamescu, Dan's son, denied that his father had affiliations with [[Black Cube]]. [[HotNews.ro]] had claimed Adamescu was a client of Black Cube.<ref name=EJ/><ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.business-review.eu/sidebar-featured/dan-adamescus-family-rejects-any-involvement-in-black-cube-dnas-kovesi-case-120591| title= Dan Adamescu’s family rejects any involvement in Black Cube – DNA’s Kovesi case| work=Business Review| date=4 October 2016| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> In the same month, Ademescu's ex-wife attempted to sue him for ownership of the [[Unirea Shopping Center]].<ref>{{cite news| url= http://www.romania-insider.com/romanian-multi-millionaire-fights-ex-wife-control-landmark-shopping-center-bucharest/| title= Romanian multi-millionaire fights ex-wife over control of landmark shopping center in Bucharest| work=Romanian Insider| date=11 October 2016| accessdate=28 January 2017}}</ref>
==Arrest and trial== In 2013, Adamescu's company Astra Insurance went bankrupt; his family blamed the Romanian state for causing the bankruptcy.<ref name=BR/> During the bankruptcy trial, Adamescu was alleged to have bribed judges €20,000.<ref name=Gulf>{{cite news| url= http://gulftoday.ae/portal/53b772f2-b135-4549-a815-7dccf0b572a3.aspx| title= Dan Adamescu, Romania's businessman serving prison, has died| work=[[The Gulf Today]]| date=24 January 2017| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref name=BR2>{{cite news| url= http://www.business-review.eu/news/romanian-millionaire-dan-adamescu-gets-jail-sentence-for-bribery-106964| title= Home » News » Romanian millionaire Dan Adamescu gets jail sentence for bribery Romanian millionaire Dan Adamescu gets jail sentence for bribery| work=Business Review| date=27 May 2016| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref><ref name=BI>{{cite news| url= http://www.balkaninsight.com/en/article/new-big-names-go-behind-bars-in-romanian-corruption-case| title= Romania Jails Four Judges and Mogul for Corruption| last=Chiriak| first=Marian| work=[[Balkan Insight]]| date=3 February 2015| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> In May 2014, [[Victor Ponta]] predicted that Adamescu would be arrested for corruption. Adamescu was arrested a few weeks afterwards.<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/jan/10/romanias-corruption-fight-is-a-smokescreen-to-weaken-its-democracy| title= Romania's corruption fight is a smokescreen to weaken its democracy| last=Clark| first=David| work=[[The Guardian]]| date=10 January 2017| accessdate=27 January 2017}}</ref> In the same year, one of the judges was arrested, after which Adamescu's lawyer allegedly committed suicide by throwing himself under a train.<ref name=Gulf/><ref name=BR2/> In March 2016, Adamescu was charged with causing $191 million of damages to Astra Insurance.<ref name=ND/> In May 2016, he was sentenced to four years and four months in jail for corruption.<ref name=Forbes/><ref name=BR/><ref name=Gulf/><ref name=ND/><ref name=BR2/>
==Illness and death== In November 2016, Adamescu's [[parole]] request, based on ill health, was rejected by a local court.<ref name=BR/><ref name=Forbes/> In December, he had knee surgery, after which he developed infections.<ref name=BR/> He was in an [[induced coma]] from December 2016 until his death on 24 January 2017, and had been suffering from [[septicemia]].<ref name=ND/><ref name=Forbes/> Adamescu was buried in the Lutheran section of [[Bellu Cemetery]].<ref name=b1>{{cite news| url= http://www.b1.ro/stiri/eveniment/update-sotia-lui-dan-adamescu-rupe-tacerea-voi-lua-toate-masurile-necesare-drept-la-replica-al-lui-alexander-adamescu-foto-174955.html?page=1| title= Soția lui Dan Adamescu rupe tăcerea | last=| first=| work=[[B1 TV]]| date=25 January 2017| accessdate=29 January 2017}}</ref>
==Personal life== Adamescu was married to Carmen Palade, general manager of [[Unirea Shopping Center]] for "many years".<ref name="Romania Insider">{{cite news |title=Late billionaire’s ex-wife held for embezzlement in Romania |url=https://www.romania-insider.com/late-billionaires-ex-wife-held-for-embezzlement-in-romania/ |accessdate=11 October 2018 |work=Romania Insider |date=10 October 2018}}</ref> As of October 2018, Palade is being held by Romanian authorities after "several hours of hearings" on suspicion of embezzlement and tax evasion.<ref name="Romania Insider"/> Palade had fought for control of the Nova Group with her husband and stepson, Alexander Adamescu, and was removed as head of Nova in 2017, with ALexander taking over after his father's death.<ref name="Romania Insider"/>
== Arrest of his son == Alexander Adamescu, a director of his father's company,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/european-arrest-warrant-brexit-david-davis-hardline-tory-mps-julian-assange-a7882146.html|title=If hardline Tory MPs get their way, London will become the new 'Costa Del Crime' after Brexit|date=2017-08-08|work=The Independent|access-date=2017-09-18|language=en-GB}}</ref> was accused by Romania’s [[National Anticorruption Directorate]] (DNA) of consenting to bribery.<ref name=":3">{{Cite web|url=http://www.friendsofalexanderadamescu.org/wp-content/uploads/on-the-abuses-in-the-romanian-arrest-warrant-procedure-of-Alexander-Adamescu.pdf|title=Memorandum on the Abuses in the Romanian Arrest Warrant Procedure of Alexander Adamescu|last=Heikkila|first=Eeva|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> In May 2016 Romanian courts issued two national arrest warrants against Adamescu and then converted into a [[European Arrest Warrant]] in connection with his father's case. On 13 June 2016, he was arrested by British police. In an interview with [[The Times]], he said he “fears that he will die in prison like his father if the Romanian government secures his extradition.<ref name=":6">{{Cite news|url=https://www.thetimes.co.uk/edition/news/playwright-snared-by-law-he-backed-cdt6cms86|title=Playwright snared by law he backed|last=Brown|first=Chad Greggor, David|access-date=2017-07-13|language=en}}</ref>
On 29 March 2017 during a hearing involving Adamescu's Dutch holding company Nova Group Investments and Romania, the [[International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes|International Centre for the Settlement of Investment Disputes]] tribunal recommended that Romania withdraw (or otherwise suspend operation of) the European Arrest Warrant against Adamescu,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hrwf.eu/wp-content/uploads/2017/04/Romania-abuses-the-European-Arrest-Warrant-a-new-report-says.pdf|title=Romania-abuses-the-European-Arrest-Warrant-a-new-report-says|last=|first=|date=|website=hrwf.eu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=18 September 2017}}</ref> and called upon Romania to “refrain from reissuing or transmitting any other EAW against him”.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europeanbusinessreview.eu/page.asp?pid=1894|title=Questions asked of Romania’s cooperation with its international commitments - Analyses - EBR|website=www.europeanbusinessreview.eu|access-date=2017-09-18}}</ref> On 10 April 2017, Romania asked the ICSID to reconsider its recommendation but this was rejected and the recommendation upheld.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.europeanbusinessreview.eu/page.asp?pid=1894|title=Questions asked of Romania’s cooperation with its international commitments - Analyses - EBR|website=www.europeanbusinessreview.eu|access-date=2017-07-13}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
