revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=her daughter, [[Ivanka Trump]]}} {{pp-vandalism|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Ivana Trump | image = Ivana Trump cropped retouched.jpg | caption = Trump in 2007 | birth_name = Ivana Marie Zelníčková | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1949|2|20}} | birth_place = [[Zlín]], [[Czechoslovak Socialist Republic|Czechoslovakia]] | occupation = {{flatlist| *Businesswoman *model }} | alma_mater = [[Charles University]] | years_active = 1970–present | spouse = {{plainlist| * {{marriage|Alfred Winklmayr
|1971|1973|reason=divorced}} * {{marriage|[[Donald Trump]]|April 7, 1977|March 22, 1992|end=divorced}} * {{marriage|Riccardo Mazzucchelli
|1995|1997|reason=divorced}} * {{marriage|Rossano Rubicondi
|2008|2009|reason=divorced}} }} | children = {{plainlist| * [[Donald Trump Jr.]] * [[Ivanka Trump]] * [[Eric Trump]] }} | family = }} '''Ivana Marie Trump''' (''[[née]]'' '''Zelníčková'''; {{IPA-cs|ˈzɛlɲiːtʃkovaː|lang}}, born February 20, 1949) is a Czech former model and businesswoman, who was the first wife of [[Donald Trump]]. They married in 1977 and divorced in 1992. They have three children together, [[Donald Trump Jr.]], [[Ivanka Trump]], and [[Eric Trump]]. ==Early life== Ivana Zelníčková was born on February 20, 1949 in the [[Moravia]]n town of [[Zlín]] (formerly known as Gottwaldov), [[Czechoslovakia]], the daughter of Miloš Zelníček, who was [[Czech people|Czech]], and Marie Francová, who was [[Austrian people|Austrian]].[http://www.cosmopolitan.com/politics/a56426/ivana-trump-donald-trump-first-wife/ Prachi Gupta, "6 Things You Need to Know About Donald Trump's First Wife, Ivana"]. ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]''. March 16, 2017. Retrieved October 1, 2017. From the age of 13, her father nurtured and encouraged her skiing talent. In the early 1970s, she attended [[Charles University in Prague]].{{cite magazine| last1= van Meter| first1 = Johnathan| date= May 1989| title = That's Why the Lady is a Trump| trans-title = | url= https://books.google.com/books?id=xaCC4gI-zJkC&lpg=PA98&q=trump%20master's%20degree&pg=PA86&v=onepage| issn = 0890-1759| magazine = [[Spy (magazine)|Spy]]| publisher = Sussex Publishers, LLC| access-date = | via = [[Google Books]]}} According to Zelníčková, she was selected as an alternate on the Czechoslovak ski team during the [[Czechoslovakia at the 1972 Winter Olympics|1972 Winter Olympics]], her specialties being the [[Downhill (ski competition)|downhill]] and [[Slalom skiing|slalom]].Bell, B., [http://www.nydailynews.com/new-york/trumps-article-1.2715780 "They met, they saw and they conquered: Donald and Ivana Trump seemed to have it all"], ''[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York'', February 11, 1990. However, in 1989, Petr Pomezný, Secretary General of the [[Czech Olympic Committee|Czechoslovak Olympic Committee]], said, "Who is this Ivana woman, and why do people keep calling us about her? We have searched so many times and have consulted many, many people, and there is no such girl in our records."{{cite magazine | last1 = van Meter | first1 = Johnathan | date = May 1989 | title = That's Why the Lady is a Trump | trans-title = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=xaCC4gI-zJkC&q=Ivana&v=snippet | issn = 0890-1759 | magazine = [[Spy (magazine)|Spy]] | publisher = Sussex Publishers, LLC | access-date = June 30, 2013 | via = [[Google Books]] }} ==Relationships== In 1971, Zelníčková married Austrian ski instructor Alfred Winkelmayr to enable her to leave Communist Czechoslovakia.{{cite news|last=Lague|first=Louise|url = https://people.com/archive/ivana-alone-vol-33-no-11/ |title =Ivana Alone|work =People Magazine| date =March 19, 1990|access-date=November 4, 2018}}{{cite news|last=McCauley|first=Dana|url = https://www.news.com.au/finance/work/leaders/this-is-the-woman-who-made-donald-trump-a-household-name/news-story/429266fca850e552ef18f66cfd4718f6 |title =This is the woman who made Donald Trump a household name|work =People Magazine| date =May 1, 2016|access-date=November 4, 2018}}{{cite news|last=Gross|first=Michael|url=https://books.google.de/books?id=7PcJmjU_n0UC&pg=PA46&lpg=PA46&dq=new+york+magazine+ivana+trump+george+syrovatka#v=onepage&q=new%20york%20magazine%20ivana%20trump%20george%20syrovatka|title=Ivana's New Life|work=New York Magazine|date=October 15, 1990|accessdate=November 4, 2018}} She received her Austrian passport in March 1972 and left for Canada in September 1972.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/1990/02/22/personalities/6416c328-06cb-4efc-817e-03292e68d5a3/|title=PERSONALITIES|first=Chuck|last=Conconi|date=February 22, 1990|publisher=|access-date=November 22, 2017|via=www.WashingtonPost.com}} The marriage was formally dissolved in 1973. In Canada she lived with her boyfriend George (Jiři) Syrovatka whom she had been dating since 1967 and who had emigrated to Canada in 1972 and owned a ski boutique in Montreal. For the following two years, she lived in Montreal, improved her English by taking night courses at [[McGill University]],{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} and worked as a model. Her modeling jobs included promoting the [[1976 Summer Olympics]] that were being hosted in [[Montreal]]. [[File:Donald and Ivana Trump.jpg|thumb|upright|Ivana and [[Donald Trump]], 1985]] In this capacity Zelníčková was in [[New York City]] with a group of models in 1976 where she met [[Donald Trump]]. They were married in 1977 in a lavish wedding officiated by [[Norman Vincent Peale]].MJ Lee: [http://edition.cnn.com/interactive/2017/politics/state/donald-trump-religion/ ''God and the Don.''] In: ''[[CNN.com]]'', June 2, 2017. Donald and Ivana Trump became leading figures in New York society during the 1980s. They worked on several large projects, including the renovation of the [[Grand Hyatt New York|Grand Hyatt Hotel]] in New York City, construction of the [[Trump Taj Mahal Casino Resort]] in [[Atlantic City, New Jersey]], and the [[Trump Tower (New York)|Trump Tower]] on [[Fifth Avenue]] in Manhattan.[http://www.vanityfair.com/magazine/2015/07/donald-ivana-trump-divorce-prenup-marie-brenner "After The Gold Rush"]. ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]''. August 1990. Retrieved January 10, 2016. "They were married in New York during Easter of 1977. Mayor Beame attended the wedding at Marble Collegiate Church. Donald had already made his alliance with Roy Cohn, who would become his lawyer and mentor.{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1983/08/07/business/the-empire-and-ego-of-donald-trump.html|title=The Empire and Ego of Donald Trump|date=August 7, 1983|work=The New York Times|access-date=October 31, 2016}} They had three children: [[Donald Trump Jr.]] (born December 31, 1977), [[Ivanka Trump]] (born October 30, 1981), and [[Eric Trump]] (born January 6, 1984). Donald Jr. learned to speak fluent Czech (with help of his maternal grandfather), while daughter Ivanka has only basic understanding of her mother's native tongue and Eric was not exposed to the language because at the time of his birth his grandparents were already comfortable enough in using English.{{Cite web|title=Ivana Trump Now Fashions Herself As Plaza's Innkeeper|url=http://articles.mcall.com/1989-05-14/features/2690591_1_trump-tower-skis-trump-castle/2|access-date=August 11, 2016}}{{Cite web|title=Did Their Father Really Know Best?|work=New York|url=http://nymag.com/nymetro/news/people/features/10610/|access-date=August 11, 2016}} Ivana has nine grandchildren.{{cite news|last1=Corcoran|first1=Kieran|title=Dad for President! Donald Trump's five children steal the spotlight at 2016 announcement - with nine-year-old Barron looking all grown up|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3127108/Donald-Trump-s-five-children-steal-spotlight-2016-announcement-nine-year-old-Barron-looking-especially-smart.html|access-date=February 2, 2016|work=Daily Mail|date=June 16, 2015}} Ivana took a major role in [[The Trump Organization]]. She became the Vice President of Interior Design for the company, leading the signature design of Trump Tower. Afterwards, her then-husband appointed her to head up the [[Trump Castle Hotel and Casino]] as president. She became a naturalized U.S. citizen in 1988.{{cite news|agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1899&dat=19880527&id=LiEgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=YmYFAAAAIBAJ&pg=5053,3823442|title=Ivana Trump becomes U.S. citizen|date=May 27, 1988|access-date=August 21, 2015}} In October 1990, Ivana Trump's 63-year-old father died suddenly from a [[Myocardial infarction|heart attack]]. According to [[The Guardian]], her father - Miloš Zelníček - was an informer for Czechoslovakia's [[Státní bezpečnost]] (StB) [[intelligence service]] and relayed information from Ivana Trump, including a prediction that [[George HW Bush]] would win the [[United States presidential election, 1988|1988 presidential election]].{{cite news |last1=Harding |first1=Luke |title='A very different world' - inside the Czech spying operation on Trump |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2018/oct/29/czechoslovakia-spied-on-trump-to-exploit-ties-to-highest-echelons-of-us-power |accessdate=29 October 2018 |work=The Guardian |date=29 October 2018}} Ivana stood side-by-side with her husband Donald at the funeral in [[Prague]].{{cite web|author=Robert E. Tomasson|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/10/31/style/chronicle-365090.html |title=Chronicle |work=The New York Times |date=October 31, 1990 |accessdate=October 24, 2012}} Jaroslav Jansa, codename "Jarda" and secret collaborator to the [[Státní bezpečnost|StB]] also attended the funeral. That Christmas, when the family was on vacation in [[Aspen, Colorado]], Ivana Trump encountered [[Marla Maples]] on the ski slopes.{{cite web|last1=Lavin|first1=Cheryl|title=With 'Dynasty' Dead, Just Tune To The Trumps|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1990-02-18/features/9001140529_1_ivana-trump-donald-trump-marla-maples|website=Chicago Tribune|access-date=October 13, 2016}} [[File:Ivana Trump shakes hands with Fahd of Saudi Arabia.jpg|thumb|left|Ivana met with King [[Fahd of Saudi Arabia]], 1985]] The Trumps' divorce proceedings appeared on New York tabloid newspapers' covers for 11 days in a row, and [[Liz Smith (journalist)|Liz Smith]] wrote about nothing else for three months.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/28/nyregion/liz-smith-lions-of-new-york.html |title=Life Among the Boldface Names |last=Leland |first=John |date=July 30, 2017 |work=The New York Times |access-date=July 28, 2017 |page=MB1 |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}} Their divorce, in a deposition for which she accused him of rape and of pulling out handfuls of her hair, was settled in 1991. However, in 2018, in a TV interview on Good Morning Britain she stated that Donald Trump never touched her badly and that it was in fact the lawyers who had suggested to make these false accusations. A condition of settlement was that she not talk about their marriage without his permission.{{cite web | url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/07/27/ex-wife-donald-trump-made-feel-violated-during-sex | title=Ex-Wife: Donald Trump Made Me Feel 'Violated' During Sex | work=[[The Daily Beast]] | date=July 27, 2015 | accessdate=May 10, 2017 | author=Mak, Tim}} The divorce was finalized in 1992.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/politics/court-docs-reveal-donald-trump-cruel-treatment-ivana-article-1.2796179|title=Court docs reveal Donald Trump's 'cruel' treatment of Ivana|work=NY Daily News|access-date=October 15, 2017|language=en}}https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=20q1e5lIF6A In 1995, she married Riccardo Mazzucchelli.{{cite web|url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20122713,00.html|title=Riccardo, We Hardly Knew Ye : People.com|work=[[People (magazine)|People]]|accessdate=July 22, 2016}} She filed a $15 million breach of contract suit against Mazzucchelli for violating the confidentiality clause in their prenuptial agreement.{{cite web|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/ivana-muzzle-soon-to-be-ex-article-1.771313|title=Ivana wants to muzzle soon-to-be-ex|work=Daily News|location=New York|accessdate=July 22, 2016}} In 1997, Mazzucchelli sued Ivana and Donald for libel.{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/husband-sues-ivana-and-donald-trump-for-libel-1253222.html|title=Husband sues Ivana and Donald Trump for libel|date=July 29, 1997|work=[[The Independent]]|accessdate=July 22, 2016}} In the summer of 1997, she began dating Roffredo Gaetani; that continued until his death in 2005.{{Cite news| issn = 0362-4331| last = Wadler| first = Joyce| title = PUBLIC LIVES; Ivana's Boy Toy (for the Record, He's a Prince)| work = The New York Times| accessdate = March 29, 2017| date = March 20, 1998| url = https://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/20/nyregion/public-lives-ivana-s-boy-toy-for-the-record-he-s-a-prince.html}} In April 2008, Ivana, then 59, married Rossano Rubicondi, then 36.{{cite web|last=Marx |first=Linda |url=http://www.people.com/people/article/0,,20190959,00.html |title=Ivana Trump Marries for the Fourth Time - Weddings, Ivana Trump |work=People |accessdate=October 24, 2012}} The $3 million wedding for 400 guests was hosted by ex-husband Donald Trump at his [[Mar-a-Lago]] estate. Daughter Ivanka Trump was her maid of honor.[http://in.reuters.com/article/lifestyleMolt/idINN1748314820080417 Ivana Trump weds actor Rossano Rubicondi: report] Reuters On December 1, 2008, Ivana confirmed to the [[Associated Press]] that she had filed a legal separation agreement three months previously; she has stated in interviews that she and her husband have an [[on-again/off-again relationship]]. In December 2009, she said she had filed for divorce from Rubicondi;{{cite news |url=https://www.upi.com/Ivana-Trump-divorcing-husband-Rubicondi/28021261930955/ |title=Ivana Trump divorcing husband Rubicondi |date=December 27, 2009 |access-date=February 24, 2018 |publisher=United Press International }} the couple has continued to be seen together as recently as May 5, 2018.{{cite news |url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/entertainment/celebrity/ivana-trump-appeared-on-italian-%e2%80%98dancing-with-the-stars/ar-AAwR3HX?li=BBnbfcL&ocid=U453DHP/ |title=Ivana Trump Appeared On Italian Dancing With The Stars With Ex-Husband Rubicondi}} ==Career== ===Business ventures=== Soon after her divorce from Donald Trump in 1992, she developed lines of clothing, fashion jewelry and beauty products that have been sold through television shopping channels. In 2005, Trump was involved in several proposed condominium projects that ultimately failed, including the never-built [[Ivana Las Vegas]], and the Bentley Bay in Miami, Florida.{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-15-Mon-2005/business/2867912.html|title=High-Rise Development: Ivana buys into project|last=Robison|first=Jennifer|date=August 15, 2005|work=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051029050640/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Aug-15-Mon-2005/business/2867912.html|archive-date=October 29, 2005}}{{cite web|url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jul-19-Wed-2006/news/8570964.html|title=Pamela, Kid Rock finally to marry|last=Clarke|first=Norm|date=July 19, 2006|work=Las Vegas Review-Journal|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060720221601/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2006/Jul-19-Wed-2006/news/8570964.html|archive-date=July 20, 2006}} In 2010, she sued the Finnish fashion company, [[Ivana Helsinki]], accusing it of selling women's clothing that incorporates her name without permission.[http://in.reuters.com/article/idINTRE68F4BQ20100916 Ivana Trump sues Finnish designer over name:report] Reuters ===Writing=== She has written several novels, including, ''For Love Alone'' (1992), ''Free to Love'' (1993) and a [[self-help]] book called, ''The Best is Yet to Come: Coping with Divorce and Enjoying Life Again'' (1995). In June 1995, she began writing an advice column for ''[[Globe (tabloid)|Globe]]'', titled Ask Ivana, about love and life.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1957&dat=19950601&id=KHk1AAAAIBAJ&sjid=0-AFAAAAIBAJ&pg=3910,149601|title=Ask Ivana|work= [[The Daily Gazette]]|date=June 1, 1995|accessdate= November 28, 2016}} In 1998, she bought 33% of Croatia's second-largest daily newspaper - with a circulation of 100,000 - she used to travel with her parents from the Czech Republic to Croatia on vacation.{{cite web|title=Successful Beach Polo Premiere in Croatia|url=http://www.poloplus10.com/rovinj-beach-polo-cup-2016-successful-beach-polo-premiere-croatia-65141/|website=POLO+10 The Polo Magazine|date=May 19, 2016}}{{cite news|last1=Tribune New Services|title=And The Town's Name Rang A Bell With Her|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1998-01-22/news/9801220095_1_ivana-trump-donald-trump-croatia|work=Chicago Tribune|date=January 22, 1998|language=en}} In February 1999, she launched her own lifestyle magazine titled ''Ivana's Living in Style''.{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1999-02-24/lifestyle/9902230731_1_ivana-trump-miniskirt-takeout|title=Picture This: Ivana Has Her Own Magazine|last=White|first=Diane|work= [[Boston Globe]]|date=February 24, 1999|accessdate=November 29, 2016}} In 2001, she contributed an advice column for ''[[Divorce (magazine)|Divorce]]'' magazine.Zwecker, Bill, "Ivana's trump? Divorce column that shares all she's learned", ''Chicago Sun-Times'', January 24, 2001 In January 2010, Trump ended her advice column in ''[[Globe]]'' to pursue other business interests.{{cite magazine |last= Trump|first= Ivana|date= January 25, 2010|title= Bye, Bye Ivana!|magazine= [[Globe (tabloid)|Globe]]|quote=Dear Readers: After years of hard work and devoted service as GLOBE's advice columnist, I regretfully have decided to resign from the position. While I have thoroughly enjoyed being a part of the GLOBE family, as well as the many friendships that I have developed over the years, other business pursuits, both nationally and internationally, will not allow me to devote the attention necessary to the column and to my readers.|page=18}} In 2017, she released an autobiography, ''[[Raising Trump]]'', that covers her own upbringing and the early years of raising her children with [[Donald Trump]].{{cite book|last1=Trump|first1=Ivana|title=Raising Trump|date=October 2017|publisher=Gallery Books|isbn=978-1-5011-7728-6}} ==Media appearances== She played a [[cameo appearance|cameo]] role in the [[Hollywood]] film ''[[The First Wives Club]]'' (1996) with the line, "Ladies you have to be strong and independent. And remember: don't get mad, get everything."{{cite book|last1=Cettl|first1=Robert|title=Film Talk|date=2010|publisher=Wider Screenings|isbn=9780987050038|page=54}} She was the host of [[Oxygen Network]]'s reality-dating program ''[[Ivana Young Man]]'', which aired in 2006.{{cite news|last=Peyser|first=Andrea|title=Ivana: Give Me a Stud; Boy-Toy Joy On Her Dating Reality Show|url=https://nypost.com/2006/04/30/ivana-give-me-a-stud-boy-toy-joy-on-her-dating-reality-show/|accessdate=November 29, 2017|work=[[New York Post]]|date=April 30, 2006}} In 2008, she was a boardroom advisor on ''[[The Apprentice (U.S. TV series)|The Apprentice]]''. In 2010, Trump took part in the UK's ''[[Celebrity Big Brother 7 (UK)|Celebrity Big Brother]]'', finishing seventh.[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/tvshowbiz/celebbigbrother/article-1241687/Celebrity-Big-Brother-Ivana-Trump-enters-house.html Celebrity Big Brother: Ivana Trump makes a magical entrance into the house] ''Daily Mail'', January 9, 2010 ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Ivana Trump}} * {{Wikiquote inline|Ivana Trump}} * {{IMDb name | id= 0005506 | name= Ivana Trump }} {{Donald Trump}} {{Trump family}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Trump, Ivana}} [[Category:1949 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:20th-century American novelists]] [[Category:20th-century American women writers]] [[Category:21st-century American women writers]] [[Category:American people of Austrian descent]] [[Category:American people of Moravian descent]] [[Category:Charles University in Prague alumni]] [[Category:Czech businesspeople]] [[Category:Czech female models]] [[Category:Czech people of Austrian descent]] [[Category:Czech socialites]] [[Category:People from Zlín]] [[Category:Trump family|Ivana]] [[Category:Czech women in business]] [[Category:Czech expatriates in Canada]] [[Category:Czechoslovak emigrants to the United States]] [[Category:American women novelists]]

{{more citations needed|date=January 2013}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox Congressman |name=John Davis Lodge|image name= John Davis Lodge.jpg |caption=Lodge in 1935 during his acting days | ambassador_from=United States | country=Switzerland | term_start= May 19, 1983 | term_end= April 30, 1985 | predecessor=[[Faith Ryan Whittlesey]] | successor=[[Faith Ryan Whittlesey]] | president= [[Ronald Reagan]] | ambassador_from2=United States | country2=Argentina | term_start2= July 23, 1969 | term_end2= November 10, 1973 | predecessor2=Carter Lane Burgess | successor2=[[Robert Charles Hill]] | president2= [[Richard Nixon]] | ambassador_from3=United States | country3=Spain | term_start3= March 24, 1955 | term_end3= April 13, 1961 | predecessor3=[[James Clement Dunn]] | successor3=[[Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle]] | president3= [[Dwight Eisenhower]] |order4 =79th |office4 =Governor of Connecticut |term_start4 =January 3, 1951 |term_end4 =January 5, 1955 |lieutenant4 =[[Edward N. Allen]] |predecessor4 =[[Chester Bowles]] |successor4 =[[Abraham A. Ribicoff]] |state5= [[Connecticut]] |district5= [[Connecticut's 4th congressional district|4th]] |party5= [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |term_start5 = January 3, 1947 |term_end5 = January 3, 1951 |predecessor5= [[Clare B. Luce]] |successor5= [[Albert P. Morano]] |birth_date={{birth date|1903|10|20}} |birth_place=Washington, D.C. |death_date={{death date and age|1985|10|29|1903|10|20}} |death_place=New York City |resting_place = [[Arlington National Cemetery]] |spouse= [[Francesca Braggiotti]] |children= 2, including [[Lily Lodge]] |parents= [[George Cabot Lodge]]
Mathilda Frelinghuysen Davis |relatives = [[Henry Cabot Lodge]] (grandfather)
[[Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.]] (brother)
''See'' [[Lodge family]] |nationality= American |alma_mater= [[Harvard University]] (1925)
[[Harvard Law School]] (1929) |profession=Actor, lawyer, diplomat, politician |religion=[[Episcopal Church in the United States of America|Episcopalian]] |party=[[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] |branch={{flag|United States Navy}} |serviceyears = 1942-1946 (Active)
1946-1966 (Reserve) |rank=[[File:US-O6 insignia.svg|23px]] [[Captain (United States Navy)|Captain]] |battles=[[World War II]] |mawards=[[Legion of Honor]];
[[Croix de Guerre]] }} '''John Davis Lodge''' (October 20, 1903 – October 29, 1985), was an American lawyer, actor, politician, and diplomat.{{cite web|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/films-tv-people/4ce2b9f3e2e73|title=John Lodge|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/artist/john-lodge-p124529|title=John Lodge - Biography, Movie Highlights and Photos - AllMovie|website=AllMovie}} He was the [[List of Governors of Connecticut|79th Governor of Connecticut]] from 1951 to 1955, and later served as U.S. Ambassador to Spain, Argentina, and [[Switzerland]].{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1985/10/30/nyregion/john-davis-lodge-is-dead-at-82-a-politician-diplomat-and-actor.html |title=JOHN DAVIS LODGE IS DEAD AT 82; A POLITICIAN, DIPLOMAT AND ACTOR |last=Fowler |first=Glenn |date=October 20, 1985 |work=The New York Times |access-date=June 18, 2018 |language=en}} As an actor, he was often credited simply as '''John Lodge'''. He had roles in four Hollywood films between 1933 and 1935, including playing [[Marlene Dietrich]]'s lover in ''[[The Scarlet Empress]]'' and [[Shirley Temple]]'s father in ''[[The Little Colonel (1935 film)|The Little Colonel]]''. He starred or co-starred in many British and European films between 1935 and 1940. Lodge was a member of four prominent political families in the Northeast U.S.: the [[Cabot family|Cabot]], [[Lodge family|Lodge]], [[Frelinghuysen family|Frelinghuysen]] and [[Davis political family|Davis]] families. He was a direct descendant of at least seven U.S. senators, and had many other politicians in his family, including his brother, Senator [[Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.]]. ==Early life== Lodge was born in Washington, D.C. His father was [[George Cabot Lodge]], a poet, who was a scion of the prominent [[Cabot family|Cabot]] and [[Lodge family|Lodge]] families of Boston. Through his father, Lodge was a grandson of Senator [[Henry Cabot Lodge]], great-great grandson of Senator [[Elijah H. Mills]], and great-great-great-grandson of Senator [[George Cabot]]. His mother, Mathilda Elizabeth Frelinghuysen Davis, was a scion of the [[Frelinghuysen family|Frelinghuysen]] and [[Davis political family|Davis]] families. Through his mother, he was a great-great grandson of Senator [[John Davis (Massachusetts governor)|John Davis]], a great-grandson of Senator [[Frederick Theodore Frelinghuysen]], a great-great grandson of Senator [[Theodore Frelinghuysen]], and a great-great-great grandson of Senator [[Frederick Frelinghuysen (general)|Frederick Frelinghuysen]]. He had two siblings: [[Henry Cabot Lodge Jr.]], also a politician, and Helena Lodge de Streel, a baroness.{{cite web|url=http://bioguide.congress.gov/scripts/biodisplay.pl?index=L000395|title=LODGE, John Davis, (1903–1985)|publisher=[[Biographical Directory of the United States Congress]]|accessdate=July 29, 2011}}{{cite web|title=Henry Cabot Lodge, Jr. Photographs II|url=http://www.masshist.org/findingaids/doc.cfm?fa=fap039|work=The Massachusetts Historical Society|publisher=MHS|accessdate=December 24, 2011}} Lodge attended the [[Evans School for Boys]] in [[Mesa, Arizona]], [[Middlesex School]], [[Concord, Massachusetts]], Ecole de Droit, Paris, France, and [[St. Albans School (Washington, D.C.)|St. Albans School]], Washington, D.C. In 1925, he graduated from [[Harvard College]], where he was a member of the [[Fox Club (Harvard)|Fox Club]]. In 1929, he graduated from [[Harvard Law School]]. In 1932, he was admitted to the New York [[bar (law)|bar]] and commenced practice in New York City. ==Acting career== During the 1930s and after a brief career as a lawyer Lodge worked as an actor on screen and stage, appearing in starring roles in several notable productions, including some major Hollywood pictures. Lodge was affiliated with the motion picture industry and the theater from 1933 to 1942, appearing in movies such as [[Little Women (1933 film)|''Little Women'']] and ''[[The Little Colonel (1935 film)|The Little Colonel]]'' in which he played [[Shirley Temple]]'s father. He was [[Marlene Dietrich]]'s co-star in ''[[The Scarlet Empress]]''. Lodge appeared in several European-made films, in France and the United Kingdom, playing [[Bulldog Drummond]] in the 1937 film ''[[Bulldog Drummond at Bay (1937 film)|Bulldog Drummond at Bay]]''. A fluent French speaker, he performed his roles in French in [[Maurice Tourneur]]'s ''[[Koenigsmark (1935 film)|Koenigsmark]]'' (1935) and in [[Max Ophüls]]'s ''[[De Mayerling à Sarajevo]]'', in which he played the part of [[Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria|Archduke Franz Ferdinand]] (1940). In 1941, after returning to the United States, he appeared in several Broadway stage productions, including [[Lillian Hellman]]'s ''[[Watch on the Rhine (play)|Watch on the Rhine]]''.{{IBDB title|id=1091|title=Watch on the Rhine}} ==Military service== Lodge served in the [[United States Navy]] as a lieutenant and lieutenant commander from August 1942 to January 1946, and was a liaison officer between the French and American fleets. He was decorated with the rank of Chevalier in the [[French Legion of Honor]] and with the [[Croix de Guerre 1939–1945 (France)|Croix de Guerre 1939–1945]] with palm by General [[Charles de Gaulle]]. After the war he engaged in research work in economics. He retired from the United States Navy Reserve in 1966 with the rank of [[Captain (naval)|Captain]]. ==Political career== Lodge was elected as a [[Republican (United States)|Republican]] from [[Connecticut's 4th congressional district]] to the [[80th United States Congress|80th]] and [[81st United States Congress|81st Congresses]], serving from January 3, 1947 to January 3, 1951. He did not run for a third term in 1950, choosing instead to run for [[Governor of Connecticut]]. He ran against incumbent governor [[Chester Bowles]] and defeated him in what was described as a "bitter" election, in which Lodge sought to portray Bowles as an extreme left-winger.{{cite web |title=CHESTER BOWLES IS DEAD AT 85; SERVED IN 4 ADMINISTRATIONS |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1986/05/26/obituaries/chester-bowles-is-dead-at-85-served-in-4-administrations.html |first=Albin |last=Krebs |publisher=''The New York Times'' |date=May 26, 1986}} Lodge served as governor from January 1951 to January 1955; he was the first governor of Connecticut to serve after the state's rules were changed to have elections every four years instead of every two years. He was a delegate to the [[Republican National Convention]] from Connecticut in [[1952 Republican National Convention|1952]] and [[1960 Republican National Convention|1960]]. Lodge ran for re-election in 1954, but lost to Democrat [[Abraham Ribicoff]]. Local legend is that the proximate cause of Lodge's defeat was disenchantment on the part of [[Fairfield County, Connecticut|Fairfield County]] Republicans with the disruption caused by the construction of the [[Connecticut Turnpike]]. The highway is now officially named the "Governor John Davis Lodge Turnpike".{{cite web |url=http://www.westportnow.com/index.php?/v2/comments/3954/ |title=Providence Journal: I-95 in Fairfield |format=uncredited blog entry |work=WestportNow.com |publisher=Westportnow Media, Inc. |date=April 23, 2003 |accessdate=February 10, 2007 }} After stepping down as governor, Lodge was appointed [[United States Ambassador to Spain]] by President [[Dwight D. Eisenhower]], where he served from January 1955 until the end of Eisenhower's term in office in January 1961. Lodge was the national president of the non-profit organization [[Junior Achievement]], Inc. from 1963 to 1964. Lodge ran for the [[U.S. Senate]] in the [[United States Senate election in Connecticut, 1964|1964 election]]. He won the Republican nomination, but lost to incumbent senator [[Thomas J. Dodd]], 35.34% to 64.66%. He served as chairman of the Committee [[Foreign Policy Research Institute]], [[University of Pennsylvania]], 1964–1969; delegate and assistant floor leader, Connecticut Constitutional Convention, in 1965; [[United States Ambassador to Argentina]], 1969 to 1974; and [[United States Ambassador to Switzerland]], 1983. ==Personal life== He was married July 6, 1929, to actress and ballet dancer, [[Francesca Braggiotti]]; both of them appearing in the 1938 film ''Tonight at Eleven''. They had two daughters, Lily and Beatrice. [[Lily Lodge]] is the Director of the [http://www.actorsconservatory.org Actors Conservatory]. He was a resident of [[Westport, Connecticut]] until his death in New York City. He was interred in [[Arlington National Cemetery]].{{cite web|url=http://www.arlingtoncemetery.net/jdlodge.htm|title=John Davis Lodge, Captain, United States Navy & Member of Congress|first=Michael Robert|last=Patterson|website=www.arlingtoncemetery.net}} Two months after his death, the [[Connecticut Turnpike]] was renamed the Gov. John Davis Lodge Turnpike in his honor. ==Selected filmography== * ''[[The Woman Accused]]'' (1933) * ''[[Little Women (1933 film)|Little Women]]'' (1933) as Brooke * ''[[The Scarlet Empress]]'' (1934) * ''[[The Little Colonel (1935 film)|The Little Colonel]]'' (1935) * ''[[Koenigsmark (1935 film)|Koenigsmark]]'' (1935) * ''[[The Tenth Man (1936 film)|The Tenth Man]]'' (1936) * ''[[Ourselves Alone (film)|Ourselves Alone]]'' (1936) * ''[[Sensation (film)|Sensation]]'' (1936) * ''[[Bulldog Drummond at Bay (1937 film)|Bulldog Drummond at Bay]]'' (1937) * ''[[Premiere (film)|Premiere]]'' (1938) * ''[[Queer Cargo]]'' (1938) * ''[[Bank Holiday (film)|Bank Holiday]]'' (1938) * ''[[Lightning Conductor (film)|Lightning Conductor]]'' (1938) * ''[[Just like a Woman (1939 film)|Just like a Woman]]'' (1939) * ''[[Sarajevo (1940 French film)|Sarajevo]]'' (1940) ==Published works== *{{cite journal|last1=Lodge|first1=John Davis|title=The Iberian Peninsula and Western Europe|journal=Journal of International Affairs|date=1962|volume=16|issue=N.1|pages=77–78|jstor=24363099}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} {{refbegin}} {{CongBio|L000395}} *[http://politicalgraveyard.com/bio/lockyer-loftus.html#R9M0J4FIE The Political Graveyard] {{refend}} ==External links== * {{IMDb name|517099|John Lodge}} * {{IBDB name|name=John Lodge}} {{s-start}} {{s-par|us-hs}} {{USRepSuccessionBox |state = Connecticut |district = 4 |before = [[Clare B. Luce]] |after = [[Albert P. Morano]] |years = 1947–1951 }} {{s-off}} {{succession box |before=[[Chester Bowles]] |title=[[Governor of Connecticut]] |years=1951–1955 |after=[[Abraham A. Ribicoff]] }} {{s-dip}} {{s-bef|before=[[James Clement Dunn]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States Ambassador to Spain]]|years=1955–1961}} {{s-aft|after=[[Anthony Joseph Drexel Biddle]]}} {{succession box |title = [[United States Ambassador to Argentina]] |before = Carter L. Burgess |after = [[Robert C. Hill]] |years = July 23, 1969 – November 10, 1973 }} {{s-bef|before=[[Faith Ryan Whittlesey]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[United States Ambassador to Switzerland]]|years=1983–1985}} {{s-aft|after=[[Faith Ryan Whittlesey]]}} {{S-ppo}} {{Succession box | before= [[William A. Purtell]] |title= [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] nominee for [[List of United States Senators from Connecticut|United States Senator from Connecticut]]
([[Classes of United States Senators|Class 1]]) |years= [[United States Senate elections, 1964|1964]] |after= [[Lowell Weicker]]}} {{end}} {{Governors of Connecticut}} {{US Ambassadors to Spain}} {{US Ambassadors to Argentina}} {{US Ambassadors to Switzerland}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lodge, John Davis}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1985 deaths]] [[Category:Harvard Law School alumni]] [[Category:Governors of Connecticut]] [[Category:Members of the United States House of Representatives from Connecticut]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American actor-politicians]] [[Category:Cabot family]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to Spain]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to Argentina]] [[Category:Ambassadors of the United States to Switzerland]] [[Category:Connecticut Republicans]] [[Category:Republican Party state governors of the United States]] [[Category:American naval personnel of World War II]] [[Category:United States Navy officers]] [[Category:Burials at Arlington National Cemetery]] [[Category:American Episcopalians]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:Gardiner family]] [[Category:Republican Party members of the United States House of Representatives]] [[Category:Military personnel from Connecticut]] [[Category:20th-century American politicians]] [[Category:Lodge family]] [[Category:Middlesex School alumni]] [[Category:St. Albans School (Washington, D.C.) alumni]]

revision.text:
{{for|the architect|John Ronan}} {{Use Irish English|date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Johnny Ronan | image = <!-- just the filename, without the File: or Image: prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | alt = <!-- descriptive text for use by the blind and visually impaired's speech synthesis (text-to-speech) software --> | caption = | birth_name = John Ronan | birth_date = <!-- {{Birth date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}} for living people - supply only the year unless the exact date is already widely published, as per WP:DOB. For people that have died, use {{Birth date|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD}}. --> | birth_place = | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | death_place = | nationality = Irish | other_names = | occupation = Accountant, property developer | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''John Ronan''' is an Irish businessman and property developer. Ronan began his education at [[Castleknock College]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/boarding-school-for-boys-to-shut-doors-after-166-years-1.299928|title=Boarding school for boys to shut doors after 166 years|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en-US}}</ref> He went on to train as a Chartered Accountant with [[PricewaterhouseCoopers]] and by his 20s was already involved in property deals with his father, who was also a developer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/nominees-john-ronan-and-richard-barrett-1.1012378|title=Nominees: John Ronan and Richard Barrett|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/lifestyle/flash-brash-johnny-becomes-ronan-reborn-26754683.html|title=Flash, brash Johnny becomes 'Ronan reborn' - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en}}</ref>
Ronan teamed up with Richard Barret from Mayo to form [[Treasury Holdings]] in 1989. The company was one of the largest Irish commercial developers and known for landmark buildings on Dublin's skyline.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/banking-inquiry/ronan-to-claim-battersea-sale-was-not-in-the-taxpayers-best-interest-31541790.html|title=Ronan to claim Battersea sale was not in the taxpayers' best interest - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-03-24|language=en}}</ref> Treasury Holdings' first serious development was the Treasury Building on Grand Canal Street on Dublin’s southside.
The duo became a formidable force, running more than 50 projects in development including the [[Spencer Dock]] development, phase 2 of Central Park in [[Leopardstown]] and the development of 2,000 homes and an 11-acre public park near [[Foxrock]].
Among Treasury Holdings’ other high profile developments were the [[Google]] Headquarters, the [[Convention Centre Dublin]], the [[The Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company|Ritz Carlton]] and the award winning residential tower Altro Vetro.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/irish-news/heres-johnny-ronan-returns-to-the-fray-with-a-300m-war-chest-31118721.html|title=Here's Johnny! Ronan returns to the fray with a €300m war chest - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-03-24|language=en}}</ref>
The Convention Centre Dublin was Ireland’s first purpose built international conference centre. It was developed as a public private partnership between Spencer Dock Development Company Ltd and the [[Office of Public Works]] (OPW). It opened in September 2010 and has since hosted numerous events including the European People’s Party Congress in 2014, which was attended by 17 heads of state.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/convention-centre-dublin-welcomes-new-ownership-1.2303295|title=Convention Centre Dublin welcomes new ownership|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
Real Estate Opportunities, majority owned by Treasury Holdings, was responsible for building and agreeing with the sale of the Montevetro office building on Barrow Street in Dublin to Google for €99.9m in cash. It was Dublin's tallest commercial office building at the time.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2011/0217/297780-reo/|title=REO to sell Montevetro building to Google|date=2011-02-17|work=RTE.ie|access-date=2017-03-24|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sligotoday.ie/details.php?id=35554|title=Sligo Today News for Sligo County - Treasury Holdings 'to move out of NAMA within days'|last=Media|first=Dmac|website=www.sligotoday.ie|access-date=2017-03-24}}</ref>
In November 2006, Real Estate Opportunities (in which Treasury Holdings had a 60% stake) purchased [[Battersea Power Station]] and the surrounding land for €532 million (£400 million).<ref name=landmark_sold>{{cite news | title = Iconic landmark is sold for £400m |publisher=BBC News | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/london/6160773.stm | accessdate =19 May 2013 | date=30 November 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = REO buys London's Battersea power station | url = http://www.rte.ie/news/2006/1130/reo-business.html | accessdate =19 May 2013 | work=RTÉ News | date=30 November 2006 }}</ref> This was Treasury’s biggest single scheme and in 2012 it secured the largest planning permission ever granted in central London – approximately 8.5 million square feet of residential, office and retail space masterplanned by Uruguayan architect [[Rafael Viñoly]]. The scheme also includes an extension of the Northern Line Underground.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/constructionandproperty/8850340/Battersea-Power-Station-timeline.html|title=Battersea Power Station: timeline|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-london-11737658|title=Wandsworth Council backs Battersea Power Station plans|date=2010-11-12|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/constructionandproperty/6359861/Battersea-Power-Stations-5.5bn-redevelopment-could-create-15000-jobs.html|title=Battersea Power Station's £5.5bn redevelopment could create 15,000 jobs|last=Ruddick|first=By Graham|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en}}</ref> On 30 November 2011, it was officially announced that the scheme’s lenders [[Lloyds Bank]] and Ireland’s [[National Asset Management Agency]] (NAMA) would put it into Administration. It was subsequently sold to a Malaysian consortium led by [[SP Setia]], which had been in negotiations with Treasury Holdings prior to the Administration to buy the scheme. Setia hired the Treasury management team and have commenced building the Treasury scheme.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/constructionandproperty/8926900/Administrators-lined-up-to-take-control-of-Battersea-Power-Station.html|title=Administrators lined up to take control of Battersea Power Station|work=Telegraph.co.uk|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/esmagazine/power-to-the-people-a-last-lingering-look-at-battersea-before-the-cranes-move-in-8587948.html|title=Power to the people: a last lingering look at Battersea before the|date=2013-04-26|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2017-04-03|language=en-GB}}</ref>
In October 2012 the High Court appointed liquidators to Treasury Holdings and 16 related companies. The move followed a decision by Treasury not to resist a winding-up application by one of its banks, KBC, over a debt of €55m. Treasury had debts of €2.7bn, €1.7bn of which was owed to the National Asset Management Agency (NAMA).<ref>[http://www.rte.ie/news/2012/1009/340913-treasury-holdings-liquidators/ RTE News]</ref>
Johnny Ronan retained substantial assets not in Treasury Holdings and in April 2015 these were refinanced in a €300 million deal with backing from [[Colony Capital]], [[M&G Investments]], and Deutsche Bank. Ronan repaid his debts at par and exited NAMA.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.irishtimes.com/business/commercial-property/developer-johnny-ronan-exits-nama-with-backing-from-colony-and-m-g-1.2161537 | title=Developer Johnny Ronan exits Nama | work=Business | date=5 April 2015 | agency=The Irish Times | accessdate=5 April 2015 | author=O'Halloran, Barry | location=Dublin}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.rte.ie/news/business/2015/0318/687963-developer-ronan-buys-back-treasury-building-loan/|title=Developer Ronan buys back Treasury Building loan|date=2015-03-18|work=RTE.ie|access-date=2017-04-19|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/irish/ronan-and-mckillen-in-control-of-namas-hq-office-31078882.html|title=Ronan and McKillen in control of Nama's HQ office - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-04-19|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/commercial-property/back-in-the-big-time-ronan-gets-to-work-on-600m-site-35096212.html|title=Back in the big time: Ronan gets to work on €600m site - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-04-19|language=en}}</ref> The refinancing for the deal was secured on RGRE’s portfolio of 24 assets in Dublin - including three Grafton Street retail properties, the Treasury Building, a number of other buildings in Dublin 2, Kilmore House in Spencer Dock, and Connaught House in Burlington Road.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.thejournal.ie/johnny-ronan-nama-exit-2025649-Apr2015/|title=He’s back!: Johnny Ronan, property and the Celtic Tiger|last=Duffy|first=Rónán|work=TheJournal.ie|access-date=2017-04-19|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/business/johnny-ronan-gets-go-ahead-for-200m-ballsbridge-build-424436.html|title=Johnny Ronan gets go-ahead for €200m Ballsbridge build|date=2016-10-06|access-date=2017-04-19}}</ref>
== Ronan Group Real Estate == John Ronan owns and runs Ronan Group Real Estate (RGRE).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ronangrouprealestate.com/Home.aspx|title=Ronan Group Real Estate > Home|last=Estate|first=Ronan Group Real|website=www.ronangrouprealestate.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> RGRE is currently working on several notable ventures in Ireland and these have a combined worth of more than €1bn.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesspost.ie/business/ronan-plans-e1bn-of-projects-following-nama-exit-319059|title=Ronan plans €1bn of projects following Nama exit {{!}} BusinessPost.ie|last=Lyons|first=Tom|work=www.businesspost.ie|access-date=2017-03-20}}</ref> The projects include the €150m Vertium office building on Dublin's Burlington Road and a €350m office campus adjacent to AIB's headquarters in Ballsbridge. Ronan has also signed off on a €600m deal to develop Spencer Place, on Dublin’s North Docks which will be Dublin’s biggest property development since 2008.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/commercial-property/johnny-ronan-mounts-uk-offensive-to-woo-brexit-jobs-35011469.html|title=Johnny Ronan mounts UK offensive to woo Brexit jobs - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/news/environment/johnny-ronan-s-plan-to-redevelop-aib-bank-centre-is-approved-1.2819861|title=Johnny Ronan’s plan to redevelop AIB Bank Centre is approved|work=The Irish Times|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en-US}}</ref> There are also plans to construct a 22-storey Aqua Vetro tower adjoining Tara Street Dart Station.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dublinlive.ie/news/dublin-news/johnny-ronan-gets-green-light-11985795|title=Johnny Ronan gets green light for €200 million Ballsbridge build|last=Deegan|first=Gordan|date=2016-10-06|work=dublinlive|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref> A report submitted by Prof Gurdgiev of Trinity College Dublin stated that an 'upside' scenario for the development will provide a total annual economic impact of €296m a year.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/business/commercial-property/ronan-tower-to-provide-296m-spinoff-35742714.html|title=Ronan tower to provide €296m spin-off - Independent.ie|work=Independent.ie|access-date=2017-06-02|language=en}}</ref> Knight Frank also indicated support for the development by stating that Dublin can cement its position as a global technology, media and telecommunications centre if it can supply the right type of office space that is demanded by the market. The firm noted the Tara Street development to be the best example of a building that can meet the needs.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/business/property-firm-backs-ronans-tower-plan-451214.html|title=Property firm backs Ronan’s tower plan|date=2017-05-30|access-date=2017-06-02}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.ronangrouprealestate.com/ Ronan Group Real Estate]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Ronan, John}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Post-2008 Irish economic downturn]] [[Category:Irish businesspeople]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10ehf1)
revision.text:
{{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Keith Brackpool<!-- include middle initial, if not specified in birth_name --> | image = <!-- filename only, i.e. without "File:" (or "Image:") prefix or enclosing [[brackets]] --> | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = <!-- only use if different from name above --> | birth_date = 1957 <!-- {{birth date and age|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | birth_place = | residence = [[California]] | nationality = [[United Kingdom|British]] | other_names = | citizenship = [[United States|American]] | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = Business executive, investor, horse-racing industry professional | years_active = 1980s-present | era = | employer = [[Stronach Group]], Cadiz Inc. | organization = | known_for = | style = | home_town = [[Surrey]] | term = | predecessor = | successor = | boards = | website = }}
'''Keith Brackpool''' (born 1957) is a [[British people|British]]-[[United States|American]] [[investor]] and [[business executive]].<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/><ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001">{{Citation | last =Campbell | first = Duncan | title =The British businessman who aims to make $1bn taking water from the desert | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | date =February 2, 2001 | url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2001/feb/02/uk.duncancampbell | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 19, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/> After starting his career as an [[investment banker]] and [[CEO]] for Albert Fisher's North American operations,<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> he co-founded the [[water resource]] company Cadiz Inc. in 1983,<ref name="DesertSun_James_2016"> {{Citation | last =James | first = Ian | title =Plan to pump water from Mojave survives court challenges | newspaper = [[The Desert Sun]] | date =May 12, 2016 | url =http://www.desertsun.com/story/news/environment/2016/05/12/plan-sell-mojave-water-survives-court-challenges/84265952/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 25, 2017}}</ref> holding a number of executive positions including CEO, and is currently chairman of the board. In 1989 he started the company 1334 Partners LP.,<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/> which owns and invests in residential and commercial properties in California.<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/><ref name=C1/> From 2013 - 2018<ref name=A1/> he served as a shareholder and executive board member for the Stronach Group, a thoroughbred horse-racing company, and chairman of West Coast operations, including [[Golden Gate Fields]] and [[Santa Anita Park]] racetracks.<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/> Brackpool has also held public policy positions in [[California]], including co-chairman of the Agriculture and Water Transition Task Force in the administration of [[California Governor]] [[Gray Davis]], a member of the Commission on Building for the 21st Century,<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> and chairman of the [[California Horse Racing Board]].<ref name="CHBRBboard"> {{Citation | title =Board Members | newspaper = CHRB | date = | url =http://chrb.ca.gov/board_members.htm | archive-url =https://web.archive.org/web/20100127235750/http://www.chrb.ca.gov/board_members.htm | archive-date =2010-01-27 | access-date =2010-01-27 }}</ref>
==Biography== ===Early career=== Keith Brackpool was born in 1957 in [[England]], with his childhood spent in [[Surrey]]<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> and [[London]].<ref name="DailyRacingForm_2010"/> Described by ''[[The Guardian]]'' as “a buccaneering self-made businessman," in the 1980s he came to the [[United States]] as an [[investment banker]]. In the United States he headed the American division of the food distribution company Albert Fisher,<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> serving as both director<ref name="MGMT_Cadiz">{{Citation | title =Management | newspaper = cadizinc.com | date = | url =http://cadizinc.com/management/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref> and CEO of North American Operations from 1989<ref name="NYT_1989"> {{Citation | title = Executive Changes | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date = October 11, 1989 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1989/10/11/business/executive-changes-318389.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 26, 2017}}</ref> until 1991.<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> In 1983,<ref name="DesertSun_James_2016"/> Brackpool partnered with geologist Mark Liggett to found [[Cadiz Inc.]], a company focused on locating water sources for development and sale to municipalities. Studying satellite images, Liggett located an [[aquifer]] in the [[Mojave desert]] and Cadiz bought a patchwork of plots from the railroads in the area, amassing 55 square miles of "creosote crumb."<ref name="WashingtonPost_Booth_2002"> {{Citation | last =Booth | first = William | title =Water's Flow From Private Hands | newspaper = [[Washington Post]] | date =August 12, 2002 | url =https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/2002/08/12/waters-flow-from-private-hands/80fcb608-6ee4-461c-a536-905848feee30/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 25, 2017 }}</ref> Brackpool became a Cadiz Inc. director in September 1986. In 1989 he started the company 1334 Partners LP., which owns commercial real estate,<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/> and was a shareholder in a [[Polly Peck]] subsidiary.<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/>
===Cadiz Inc.=== In the mid-1990s,<ref name="DesertSun_James_2016"/> Cadiz developed a water transport plan that involved storing excess water from the [[Colorado River]] in an aquifer on Cadiz property, with the water to be sold to California communities during droughts.<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> The proposal was developed with<ref name="DesertSun_James_2016"/> and then pitched to the [[Metropolitan Water District|Metropolitan Water District of Southern California]] (MET) of southern California, and at the time was considered “the largest public-private project in the state's history."<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> In 2001 Brackpool was appointed [[chairman]] of the Cadiz Inc. board of directors in addition to his roles as president and CEO.<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"> {{Citation | title =Keith Brackpool | newspaper = [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] | date = | url =https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=294784&privcapId=294780 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 19, 2017}}</ref> After federal approval of the project in 2002,<ref name="WSJ_Squeo_2002"/> controversy surrounded the water proposal, with critics such as Senator [[Dianne Feinstein]]<ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Groundwater_2012"> {{Citation | title =San Bernardino County approves Cadiz groundwater pumping plan | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date =October 1, 2012 | url =http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/lanow/2012/10/cadiz-groundwater-pumping-plan-approved.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = March 26, 2017}}</ref><ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Boxall_2015"> {{Citation | last =Boxall | first = Bettina | title =BLM decision sets back Cadiz plan to sell Mojave groundwater | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date =October 5, 2015 | url =http://www.latimes.com/science/la-me-cadiz-desert-water-20151006-story.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017}}</ref> disagreeing with the [[U.S. Interior Department]]’s assessment that "any negative effects on the environment could be prevented."<ref name="WSJ_Squeo_2002"/>
During early processing of the water proposal with MET, Cadiz was also involved in agricultural development.<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> In 1993, Cadiz secured permits from [[San Bernardino County]] to expand its agricultural operations and develop up to 9,600 acres of its properties in the Mojave Desert.<ref name="TheSun_Steinberg_OK_1993"> {{Citation | last =Steinberg | first = Jim | title =Farm expansion wins OK | newspaper = [[The San Bernardino Sun]] | date =November 6, 1993 | page =16 | url =https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/91010881/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 28, 2017}}</ref> In 1996 the Cadiz Land Company acquired Sun World International Inc., which had been in [[Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection]] since 1994. At the time, Cadiz Land grew fruit and vegetables and owned 42,000 acres in Southern California.<ref name="TheNewYorkTimes_SunWorld_1996"> {{Citation | last = | first = | title =Cadiz Land plans to buy Sun World for $175 million | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | date =May 29, 1996 | url =https://www.nytimes.com/1996/05/29/business/company-news-cadiz-land-plans-to-buy-sun-world-for-175-million.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref> Brackpool also expanded into international projects, exploring a development in [[Egypt]] which the company hoped would "become the largest single agricultural project in the world."<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> In 1998<ref name="Bloodhorse_Shinar_2009">{{Citation | last = Shinar | first = Jack | title = Brackpool, Rosenberg Appointed to CHRB | newspaper = Blood Horse | date = September 24, 2009 | url = http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/146626/brackpool-rosenberg-appointed-to-chrb | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017 }}</ref> Brackpool was appointed co-chairman of the Agriculture and Water Transition Task Force in the administration of California governor [[Gray Davis]],<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> and in 1999<ref name="Bloodhorse_Shinar_2009"/> Davis appointed him to the Commission on Building for the 21st Century.<ref name="TheGuardian_Campbell_2001"/> In October 2002 the board of the MET voted against the project "by a razor-thin margin."<ref name="WSJ_Squeo_2002"> {{Citation | last =Marie Squeo | first = Anne | title =Cadiz's Proposed Water Deal Is Scrapped by Cooperative | newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date =October 9, 2002 | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB1034125058868531156 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017 }}</ref> Sun World filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in early 2003<ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Douglass_2003"> {{Citation | last =Douglass | first =Elizabeth | title =Cadiz Subsidiary Files for Chapter 11 | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date =January 31, 2003 | url =http://articles.latimes.com/2003/jan/31/business/fi-cadiz31 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref> and was sold by Cadiz in 2005 to Black Diamond Capital Management for $127.8 million.<ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Black_2005">{{Citation | title =Black Diamond Buys Sun World Assets | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Times]] | date =March 1, 2005 | url =http://articles.latimes.com/2005/mar/01/business/fi-rup1.2 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref>
In 2009, Cadiz announced a new project design<ref name="DesertSun_James_2016"/> focused on supplying fresh water solely from the Cadiz aquifer<ref name="SantaMargarita_2012"/> to 400,000 Southern Californians.<ref name="Sun_Steinberg_2015"> {{Citation | last =Steinberg | first = Jim | title =Diverse group of 11 trade, labor and agencies file briefs in support of Cadiz project | newspaper = [[The San Bernardino Sun]] | date =September 2, 2015 | url =http://www.sbsun.com/environment-and-nature/20150902/diverse-group-of-11-trade-labor-and-agencies-file-briefs-in-support-of-cadiz-project | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="TheSun_Steinberg_Roadblock_2015">{{Citation |last = Steinberg |first = Jim |title = Cadiz chief to tackle desert water transfer project |newspaper = [[The San Bernardino Sun]] |date = October 11, 2015 |url = http://www.sbsun.com/environment-and-nature/20151011/cadiz-chief-to-tackle-desert-water-transfer-project-roadblock%20/ |archive-url = |archive-date = |access-date = May 26, 2017 }}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> According to Cadiz, the Cadiz Valley Water Conservation Recovery and Storage Project would pump groundwater before it evaporates and deliver it via an underground pipeline<ref name="SantaMargarita_2012"/> stretching 43 miles, to be constructed within an existing railroad corridor.<ref name="DesertSun_James_2016"/> Brackpool stepped down as president of Cadiz Inc. on April 12, 2011,<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/> while the proposal was still in its environmental review phase,<ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Groundwater_2012"/> with colleague Scott Slater taking over.<ref name="Sacbee_2017"/> He remained CEO and chairman.<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/> The [[Santa Margarita, California|Santa Margarita]] Water District approved the project’s environmental documents in July 2012,<ref name="SantaMargarita_2012">{{Citation |title = Cadiz Project - CEQA Documents and PDF of the Final Environmental Impact Report |publisher = [[Santa Margarita, California|Santa Margarita]] Water District |date = July 31, 2012 |url = http://www.smwd.com/operations/the-cadiz-project-ceqa-documents.html |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20170522172504/http://www.smwd.com/operations/the-cadiz-project-ceqa-documents.html# |archive-date = 2017-05-22 |access-date = May 28, 2017 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref> followed by approval of the project by the [[San Bernardino County]] Board of Supervisors in October 2012.<ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Groundwater_2012"/>
In 2013, Slater assumed the CEO role,<ref name="Sacbee_2017"> {{Citation | last = Shinar | first = Jack | title = California water venture tied to Trump sees prospects rise after years of setbacks | newspaper =[[The Sacramento Bee]] | date = February 8, 2017 | url = http://www.sacbee.com/news/state/california/water-and-drought/article131319144.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017}}</ref> while Brackpool remained chairman of the Cadiz board.<ref name="MGMT_Cadiz"/> The project faced several lawsuits between 2012 and 2014 brought by environmental groups and local oil and gas operatives that mine the desert for salt. In May 2014, the Superior Court rejected all claims against the project and upheld the approvals.<ref name="OC_Register_Zimmerman_2014"> {{Citation | last =Zimmerman | first = Janet | title =Judge sinks lawsuits against Cadiz Valley water project | newspaper = [[OC Register]] | date =May 5, 2014 | url =http://www.ocregister.com/articles/water-612772-project-environmental.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017}}</ref> These rulings were subsequently appealed to the California Court of Appeal,<ref name="Sun_Steinberg_2015"/> which sustained the lower court rulings in May 2016 and upheld the project's approvals.<ref name="TheSun_Steinberg_Win_2016"> {{Citation | last =Steinberg | first = Jim | title =Cadiz water project in Mojave Desert wins big in Appellate Court | newspaper = [[The San Bernardino Sun]] | date =May 10, 2016 | url =http://www.sbsun.com/environment-and-nature/20160510/cadiz-water-project-in-mojave-desert-wins-big-in-appellate-court | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref> The project approval process proved politically controversial.<ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Boxall_2015"/><ref name="LosAngelesTimes_Groundwater_2012"/><ref name="WeeklyStandard_Swift_2015"> {{Citation | last =Swift | first = Jim | title =Riders on the Storm | newspaper = [[The Weekly Standard]] | date =November 9, 2015 | url =http://www.weeklystandard.com/riders-on-the-storm/article/1060864 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 28, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="TheSun_Steinberg_Roadblock_2015"/><ref name="WSJ_Finley_2016"> {{Citation | last =Finley | first = Allysia | title =Trying to Get Water to California but Torpedoed by Regulators | newspaper = [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date =April 8, 2016 | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/trying-to-get-water-to-california-but-torpedoed-by-regulators-1460154453 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017 }}</ref><ref name="WallStreetJournal_Seller_2016">{{Citation | title =The Pipeline and the Short Seller | newspaper = [[Wall Street Journal]] | date =August 16, 2016 | url =https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-pipeline-and-the-short-seller-1471388783 | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 26, 2017}}</ref><ref name="Sacbee_2017"/> Under a [[Trump Administration]] change of policy, the project may not have to undergo federal review.<ref name="LATimes_2017"> {{Cite news| last =Boxall | first = Bettina | title =Trump eases the way for a controversial water pumping project in a California desert | newspaper = [[The Los Angeles Times]] | date =April 4, 2017 | url =http://www.latimes.com/local/lanow/la-me-trump-cadiz-20170404-story.html}}</ref> As of 2018, Brackpool continues to serve as chairman of the Cadiz board.<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/>
===Horse racing positions=== Brackpool was appointed to the [[California Horse Racing Board]] (CHRB) by Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]] on September 24,<ref name="CBTAF">{{Citation | title =News | newspaper = CTBA | date = | url =http://www.ctba.com/092news/calbreds0456h.htm | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = }}{{dead|date=May 2017}}</ref> 2009, and he was elected chairman<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/> on January 15, 2010.<ref name="ctba">{{cite web|url=http://www.ctba.com/101news/calbreds0030c.htm|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101121183117/http://ctba.com/101news/calbreds0030c.htm |archive-date=2010-11-21 |dead-url=yes|title=New Chairman for CHRB | California Thoroughbred Breeders Association|accessdate=2016-06-20}}</ref><ref name="CHBRBboard"/> Later in 2010, Brackpool stated at a [[California Thoroughbred Breeders Association]] and [[Oak Tree Racing Association]] conference that the racing industry needed to increase audience attendance by improving the onsite experience. He also argued for exchange wagering as an alternative to “ontrack casino wagering," stating "if you could merge British racing experience with the [[American football]] model, you would have the greatest thing you could experience."<ref name="BloodHorse_Arrington_2010">{{Citation | last =Arrington | first = Debbie | title =Put the Fun Back in Racing, Brackpool Urges | newspaper = Blood Horse | date =September 26, 2010 | url =http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/140248/put-the-fun-back-in-racing-brackpool-urges | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref> Along with other members of the board, Brackpool worked for greater distribution of races through channels such as [[Horse Racing TV|HRTV]] and [[TVG Network|TVG]].<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/>
In January 2013, Brackpool left his role as chairman of the CHRB and became a shareholder<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/> and member of the executive board at the [[Stronach Group]].<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/><ref name="Stronach_Team">{{Citation | title =Stronach Group Team | newspaper = stronachgroup.com | url =http://www.stronachgroup.com/team | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 19, 2017}}</ref> He was appointed chairman and head of [[Stronach Group]]’s operations on the west coast,<ref name="BloodHorse_TakesOver_2015"/> which includes the [[Golden Gate Fields]] and [[Santa Anita Park]] racetracks.<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"/> In his position with the Stronach Group in 2013 he oversaw the restoration and expansion of San Luis Rey Downs, which had seen a surge of activity as a training center after the closure of nearby [[Hollywood Park Racetrack|Hollywood Park]].<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Hovdey_2013"> {{Citation | last =Hovdey | first = Jay | title =San Luis Rey Downs, a relic of 1970s, comes back into style | newspaper = [[Daily Racing Form]] | date =December 12, 2013 | url =http://www.drf.com/news/jay-hovdey-san-luis-rey-downs-relic-1970s-comes-back-style | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref>
In 2013 Brackpool was<ref name="PasadenaStarNews_Favot_Returns_2013">{{Citation | last =Favot | first = Sarah | title =Racing returns to Santa Anita as track unveils $15M renovation to appreciative fans | newspaper = [[Pasadena Star News]] | date =September 27, 2013 | url =http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/140858/stronach-santa-anita-to-have-dirt-main-track | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 29, 2017 }}</ref> temporarily named CEO of the Santa Anita racetrack.<ref name="BloodHorse_TakesOver_2015">{{Citation | title =Brackpool Takes Over Santa Anita Operations | newspaper = www.bloodhorse.com | date =April 23, 2015 | url =http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/107872/brackpool-takes-over-santa-anita-operations | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 25, 2017 }}</ref> In the summer of 2013, Brackpool renovated Santa Anita Park, and [[thoroughbred horse racing]] returned to the park in September. He explained that the renovations “were centered around improving the audiovisual experience at the track" as well as visitor experience, with the [[country club|clubhouse]], [[sports bar]], and Chandelier Room upgraded.<ref name="PasadenaStarNews_Favot_Returns_2013"/> In 2013, Brackpool renovated Santa Anita Park. According to ''[[Daily Racing Form]]'', the renovations met with “generally positive reviews."<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Hovdey_2013"/> In December 2013, Santa Anita began installing a new dirt track surface, after changes in state legislation made synthetic turf no longer a requirement.<ref name="LosAngelesDailyNews_Favot_2014">{{Citation | last =Favot | first = Sarah | title =Santa Anita to get new dirt track surface | newspaper = [[Los Angeles Daily News]] | date =June 15, 2014 | url =http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/sports/20140615/santa-anita-to-get-new-dirt-track-surface | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref> Attendance at Santa Anita improved over the following two years.<ref name="BloodHorse_AnitaGains_2015">{{Citation | title =Santa Anita Reports Attendance, Handle Gains | newspaper =Blood Horse | date =July 1, 2015 | url =http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/106558/santa-anita-reports-attendance-handle-gains | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 29, 2017 }}</ref> Along with his Santa Anita roles, through his positions at Stronach<ref name="BloodHorse_Shinar_2012">{{Citation | last = Shinar | first = Jack | title = Deal to Put Santa Anita On TVG Discussed | newspaper =Blood Horse | date = July 19, 2012 | url = http://www.bloodhorse.com/horse-racing/articles/127925/deal-to-put-santa-anita-on-tvg-discussed | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref> Brackpool was chairman of [[Golden Gate Fields]]<ref name="East_Bay_2016">{{Citation | last =Esper | first = Damin | title =Albany: Golden Gate Fields donates land for Bay Trail | newspaper = [[East Bay Times]] | date =May 19, 2016 | url =http://www.eastbaytimes.com/2016/05/19/albany-golden-gate-fields-donates-land-for-bay-trail/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref> and chairman of the Los Angeles Turf Club.<ref name="DRF_Hovdey_2016">{{Citation | last =Hovdey | first = Jay | title = Hovdey: Santa Anita builds, hoping people will come | newspaper = [[Daily Racing Form]] | date =December 22, 2015 | url =http://www.drf.com/news/hovdey-santa-anita-builds-hoping-people-will-come | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 29, 2017 }}</ref> At the conclusion of a five year term, in April 2018, Brackpool stepped down from his positions at Stronach.<ref name=A1/>
==Real estate investments== Personally invested in a number of real estate projects, since 1989 Brackpool has owned 1334 Partners LP., which holds commercial real estate.<ref name="Bloomberg_Brackpool"/> Brackpool was the longtime owner of the Manhattan Country Club,<ref name=C1>{{Citation |last=Beth Solomon |first=Daina |year=June 6, 2017 |title=Manhattan Country Club Sold for $73 Million |publisher=[[Los Angeles Business Journal]] |publication-place=Los Angeles, California, United States |page= |url=http://labusinessjournal.com/news/2017/jun/06/manhattan-country-club-sold-73-million/ |accessdate= October 14, 2018}}</ref> which has hosted since 1994 the annual Manhattan Wine Auction, a popular fundraising event.<ref name="BeachReporter_Curnutt_2014"> {{Citation | last = Curnutt | first = Jim | title = Manhattan Wine Auction a barrel of fun | newspaper = [[The Beach Reporter]] | date = June 20, 2014 | url =http://tbrnews.com/news/manhattan-wine-auction-a-barrel-of-fun/article_d28be220-f8d4-11e3-86bd-0019bb2963f4.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 19, 2017 }}</ref> In June 2017, Brackpool sold the Manhattan Country Club to Bay Club Co. for $73 million.<ref name=C1/>
==Legal matters== Brackpool and Stronach are involved in litigation over the amount due Brackpool from his time at Stronach, estimated to be around $40 million.<ref name=A1>{{Citation |last=Paulick |first=Ray |year=April 14, 2018 |title=Deal Or No Deal? Brackpool Sues Stronach Group Over $40-Million Equity Stake |publisher=Paulick Report |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.paulickreport.com/news/nl-art-1/deal-or-no-deal-brackpool-sues-stronach-group-over-40-million-equity-stake/ |accessdate=October 14, 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{Citation |last=Hegarty |first=Matt |year=October 11, 2018 |title=Stronach files $400M lawsuit against daughter, former CEO |publisher=DRF |publication-place= |page= |url=https://www.drf.com/news/stronach-files-400m-lawsuit-against-daughter-former-ceo |accessdate=October 14, 2018 }}</ref>
According to ''[[The Guardian]]'', early in his career Brackpool “breached financial disclosure laws” in the United Kingdom.<ref name="Billions_Guardian_2016"> {{Citation | last =Neate | first = Rupert | title =How one man plans to make billions selling Mojave desert water | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | date =January 3, 2016 | url =https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2016/jan/03/scott-slater-cadiz-plans-make-billions-selling-mojave-desert-water | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 25, 2017 }}</ref>
==Personal life== A single father of two children, Brackpool lives in [[California]].<ref name="DailyRacingForm_2010">{{Citation | last =Andersen | first = Steve | title =New chairman anything but bored | newspaper = [[Daily Racing Form]] | date =January 21, 2010 | url =http://www.drf.com/news/new-chairman-anything-bored | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 26, 2017 }}</ref> Brackpool is an active [[thoroughbred]] owner<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2013"> {{Citation | last =Andersen | first = Steve | title =Brackpool resigns from CHRB to take position with Stronach Group | newspaper = [[Daily Racing Form]] | date =January 18, 2013 | url =http://www.drf.com/news/brackpool-resigns-chrb-take-position-stronach-group | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 19, 2017 }}</ref> with both personal ownership of race horses<ref name="PasadenaStar_Diroll_Blue_2014"/> and a stakeholder position<ref name="ThoroughbredNews_Martini_2015"/> in Golden Pegasus Racing,<ref name="Kentucky_Clay_2015">{{Citation | title =John Clay: Carla Gaines, trainer of Derby contender Bolo, left psychology for the racetrack | newspaper = Kentucky.com | date =April 28, 2015 | url =http://www.kentucky.com/sports/spt-columns-blogs/john-clay/article44596590.html | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref> a partnership with other Stronach Group executive board members.<ref name="ThoroughbredNews_Martini_2015"> {{Citation | last = Martini | first = Jessica | title = Winning Agenda for Brackpool | newspaper = Thoroughbred Daily News | date = December 28, 2015 | url = http://www.thoroughbreddailynews.com/winning-agenda-for-brackpool/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref> In January 2014, Brackpool's horse Gervinho competed in the Grade II [[Sir Beaufort Stakes]] with jockey [[Rafael Bejarano]], winning the $200,000 purse.<ref name="PasadenaStar_Diroll_Blue_2014"> {{Citation | last =Diroll | first = Patt | title =On The Town: Santa Anita opening: Blue skies and blue jeans | newspaper = [[Pasadena Star News]] | date =January 5, 2014 | url =http://www.pasadenastarnews.com/lifestyle/20140105/on-the-town-santa-anita-opening-blue-skies-and-blue-jeans | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 29, 2017 }}</ref> Other notable horses owned by Brackpool have included [[Dynaformer]]’s sons Kolo and Bolo, who both won the Santa Anita [[Eddie Logan Stakes]] at two years of age.<ref name="WCourier_Journal_2015"> {{Citation | last =Lintner | first = Jonathan | title =What's in the name for 2015's Derby horses? | newspaper = [[Courier Journal]] | date =April 29, 2015 | url =http://www.courier-journal.com/story/sports/horses/triple/derby/2015/04/29/kentucky-derby-2015--whats-in-the-name-for-2015s-derby-horses/26572899/ | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date =May 29, 2017 }}</ref> In February 2016 Bolo won the Grade 2 [[Arcadia Handicap]] at Santa Anita in an upset.<ref name="DailyRacingForm_Andersen_2016"> {{Citation | last =Andersen | first = Steve | title = Bolo fires fresh in Arcadia Stakes | newspaper = [[Daily Racing Form]] | date =February 13, 2016 | url =http://www.drf.com/news/bolo-fires-fresh-arcadia-stakes | archive-url = | archive-date = | access-date = May 29, 2017}}</ref>
