{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{unreferenced|date=April 2013}} {{MedalTableTop|medals= {{Medal|Sport|Men's [[Olympic weightlifting|Weightlifting]]}} {{Medal|Country|{{flag|Malaya}}}} {{Medal|Comp|[[British Empire Games]]}} {{Medal|Gold | [[1950 British Empire Games|1950 Auckland]] | 310.5 kg}} }} '''Koh Eng Tong''' (1921-2006) was a [[Malaysian people|Malaysian]] athlete, professional [http://www.photographermalaysia.my/ photographer] and founder of Eng Tong System Sdn. Bhd, a supplier of professional photographic equipment and other products in [[Malaysia]]. He won the first [[Commonwealth Games]] gold medal for [[Federation of Malaya|Malaya]] and was instrumental in bringing Malaysian sports to world prominence. == British Empire and the Commonwealth Games == In 1950, Koh Eng Tong won Malaya's first Gold Medal at the [[1950 British Empire Games]] in Weightlifting (featherweight) held in [[Auckland]], New Zealand. At these games he lifted 310.5 kg (684.5 lbs) to win the featherweight Gold. Although at the time, Malaya was not yet an independent country, the British Government in Malaya allowed an organised a team of four weightlifters from Malaya to participate for the first time in the Games under the Union Jack. The 1950 games was also the first occasion weightlifting was introduced. Due to the absence of a sports organisation, the weightlifters had to pay their own expenses to participate at the games. All four lifters medaled, bringing back 2 gold, 1 silver, and 1 bronze. In 1951, he was rated one of the top ten Featherweight Lifters in the World{{by whom|date=April 2013}}. In 1954, due to lack of financial support, Malaya could not participate in the [[1954 British Empire and Commonwealth Games]] held in Vancouver, and Koh was not given an opportunity to defend his title, which might have resulted in a repeat victory. The 1954 winning weight in the featherweight category was 690 lbs, 5 lbs more than the total achieved by Koh Eng Tong in 1950. == Olympic games == Malaya was officially recognised by the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) in 1954. Mr. Koh was among a contingent of 33 athletes sent by the [[Federation of Malaya Olympic Council]] to participate in the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in Melbourne. Although 6 years removed from his gold medal performance at the British Empire games. Mr. Koh represented Malaya in the featherweight weightlifting category. It was the first of two Olympic appearance by the nation under the Malaya name. He lifted 285 kg (628 lbs), well off his personal best during his prime and finish in 17th place. == Hall of Fame == In 1994, Eng Tong was recognised by the Olympic Council of [http://www.photographermalaysia.my/ Malaysia] and inducted to the Hall of Fame. Mr. Koh presented to Olympic Council of Malaysia (OCM) with a classic photo which he took in the [[1956 Summer Olympics]] in Melbourne. [http://www.olympic.org.my/museum/hof/ind/ket.htm "Iron Man of Malaya"] == 1998 Commonwealth Games == When Kuala Lumpur hosted the [[1998 Commonwealth Games]] Eng Tong was honoured by becoming the [[Queen's Baton Relay]] Final Runner for these games, who at 77 handed the baton which contained the Queen's message to Prince Edward, the Queen's representative and Commonwealth Games Federation president. The games were the first hosted by an Asian country and for the first time in the history of the games that all 70 Commonwealth countries took part. == Personal life == He is survived by his wife, three sons, one daughter, and ten grandchildren. ''Spouse'' - Wong Yoke Lan
''Sons'' - Ronnie Koh, Tony Koh, and Jerry Koh
''Daughter'' - Maureen Chin
''Grandchildren'' - Kevin Koh, Mervin Koh, Tracy Koh, Cindy Koh, Wendy Koh, Malcolm Koh, Patrick Koh, Darren Chin, Sharon Chin, and Brian Chin. {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Koh, Eng Tong}} [[Category:1921 births]] [[Category:2006 deaths]] [[Category:Malaysian people of Chinese descent]] [[Category:Malaysian male weightlifters]] [[Category:Weightlifters at the 1950 British Empire Games]] [[Category:Weightlifters at the 1956 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic weightlifters of Malaya]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games gold medallists for Malaya]] [[Category:Malaysian businesspeople]] [[Category:Malaysian photographers]] [[Category:Commonwealth Games medallists in weightlifting]]

{{refimprove|date=January 2015}} The '''Langley Gold Medal''', or '''Samuel P. Langley Medal for Aerodromics''', is an award given by the [[Smithsonian Institution]] for outstanding contributions to the sciences of [[aeronautics]] and [[astronautics]]. Named in honor of [[Samuel P. Langley]], the Smithsonian's third Secretary, it was authorized by the Board of Regents in 1909.<ref name = "smith"/>
The medal was suggested by [[Alexander Graham Bell]]. It is awarded for "meritorious investigations in connection with the science of aerodromics and its application to aviation".<ref name=cnn>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnn.com/TECH/space/9907/20/apollo.11.awards/|title=Apollo 11 astronauts honored for 'astonishing' mission|date=July 20, 1999|publisher=CNN|access-date=April 24, 2018}}</ref>
==List of award winners== [[File:1913_Langley_Medal_awarded_to_Glenn_Hammond_Curtiss.jpg|thumb|right|300px|Face and obverse of the 1913 Langley Medal awarded to Glenn Hammond Curtiss]] (Reference unless given individually<ref name="smith" >{{cite web |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |title=Medals and Awards |url=http://newsdesk.si.edu/about/awards |accessdate=23 March 2012}}</ref>) *1910 [[Wright Brothers|Orville and Wilbur Wright]]<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |title=Wright Brothers Receive Langley Medal |url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_9688 |accessdate=24 March 2012}}</ref> *1913 [[Glenn Curtiss]], [[Gustave Eiffel]]<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |title=Curtiss & Eiffel Awarded Langley Medal |url=http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_203 |accessdate=24 March 2012}}</ref> *1927 [[Charles Lindbergh]]<ref>{{cite news |work=[[Time magazine|Time]] |title=AERONAUTICS: Langley Medal |url=http://content.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,731300,00.html |date= |accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref> *1929 [[Charles M. Manly]] (posthumously awarded), [[Richard E. Byrd]] *1935 [[Joseph Sweetman Ames|Joseph S. Ames]] *1955 [[Jerome Clarke Hunsaker]]<ref>{{cite web |publisher=Smithsonian Institution |title=Hunsaker Receives Langley Medal |url= http://siarchives.si.edu/collections/siris_sic_1198 |accessdate=25 March 2012}}</ref> *1960 [[Robert H. Goddard]] (posthumously awarded) *1962 [[Hugh Latimer Dryden]] *1964 [[Alan Shepard]] *1967 [[Wernher von Braun]]<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1967/1967%20-%201054.html |title=Dr von Braun Honoured |work=[[Flight International]] |page=1030 |date=22 June 1967 |accessdate=8 January 2015}}</ref> *1971 [[Samuel C. Phillips]] *1976 [[James E. Webb]] *1976 [[Grover Loening]] *1981 [[Charles Stark Draper]] *1981 [[Robert Thomas Jones (engineer)|Robert T. Jones]] *1983 [[Ross Perot, Jr.]] and [[Jay Coburn]] *1987 [[Barry Goldwater]] *1992 [[Benjamin O. Davis, Jr.]] *1999 [[Neil Armstrong]], [[Buzz Aldrin]] and [[Michael Collins (astronaut)|Michael Collins]].<ref name=cnn />

{{Infobox person | name = Liban Abdi Egal
لبنان عبدي إيغال | image = | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Somalia]] | occupation = entrepreneur | title = Chairman of [[First Somali Bank]] }} '''Liban Abdi Egal''' ({{lang-so|Liibaan Cabdi Egaal}}, {{lang-ar|لبنان عبدي إيغال}}) is a [[Somali people|Somali]] entrepreneur. He is the founder and Chairman of [[First Somali Bank]] (FSB), established in 2012.{{cite news|last=Mulupi|first=Dinfin|title=Meet the Boss: Liban Abdi Egal, chairman, First Somali Bank|url=http://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/meet-the-boss-liban-abdi-egal-chairman-first-somali-bank/17619/|accessdate=30 January 2014|newspaper=How We Made It In Africa|date=20 June 2012}} ==See also== *[[Haji Mohamed Yasin Ismail]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Egal, Liban Abdi}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ethnic Somali people]] [[Category:Somalian businesspeople]] [[Category:Somalian Muslims]]

page.title: List of companies founded by Harvard University alumni

revision.text:
This is a '''list of companies founded by [[Harvard University]] alumni''', including attendees who enrolled in degree programs at Harvard University but did not eventually graduate. Companies founded by alumni of [[Radcliffe College]] ("[[Harvard Annex]]", 1879-1999) are not included in this list.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.radcliffe.harvard.edu/about-us/our-history|title=Our History|work=Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study at Harvard University|access-date=2018-05-18|language=en}}</ref> This list is not exhaustive, as it only includes notable [[Company|companies]] <!-- i.e. having articles on Wikipedia, but we don't reference Wikipedia within Wikipedia-->of which the founding and development history is well recorded by reliable sources. In particular, [[Subsidiary|subsidiaries]] are listed with their owners in parentheses.
Harvard University is a highly successful university in attracting funding for [[Startup company|start-up companies]], and its alumni have created a large number of companies.<ref>Christina Pazzanese, "Harvard's alumni impact", ''Harvard Gazette'', [https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2015/12/harvards-alumni-impact/ 8 December 2015]</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/research/university-entrepreneurship-report/|title=The University Entrepreneurship Report – Alumni of Top Universities Rake in $12.6 Billion Across 559 Deals|date=2012-10-29|work=CB Insights Research|access-date=2018-04-06|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.graphicsprings.com/founders-funding-and-exit-ranking-usa|title=Founders Funding And Exit Ranking Usa {{!}} GraphicSprings|work=Founders Funding And Exit Ranking Usa {{!}} GraphicSprings|access-date=2018-05-19|language=en}}</ref> According to [[PitchBook Data|PitchBook]], from 2006 to 2017, Harvard produced 844 company founders as alumni or current students, creating 750 companies, fourth most among all universities in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.pitchbook.com/website/files/pdf/PitchBook_Universities_Report_2017-2018_Edition.pdf|title=Universities Report: The top 50 universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs (2017-2018)|last=|first=|date=|website=PitchBook|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://files.pitchbook.com/pdf/PitchBook_Universities_Report_2016-2017_Edition.pdf|title=Universities Report: The top 50 universities producing VC-backed entrepreneurs (2016-2017)|last=|first=|date=|website=PitchBook|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
In this list, founders of a company which [[merged]] with other companies to form a new company are counted as founders of the new company. However, founders of a company which later dissolved into several successor companies are ''not'' counted as founders of those successor companies; this same rule applies to [[Spin-off (corporate)|spin-off companies]]. Finally, a defunct company is a company that had stopped functioning completely (e.g., [[Bankruptcy|bankrupt]]) without dissolving, merging or being [[Mergers and acquisitions|acquired]].
== Top companies by revenues ==
=== Fortune Global 500 (2017) === This list shows companies in [[Fortune Global 500]] founded or co-founded by Harvard alumni. The cut-off revenue for 2017 Fortune Global 500 companies is $21,609M in 2016.<ref name=":193">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/global500/list/|title=Fortune Global 500 List 2017: See Who Made It|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> {| class="wikitable sortable" |+ ! !Company !Region !Fortune Global 500 (2017)<ref name=":1932">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/global500/list/|title=Fortune Global 500 List 2017: See Who Made It|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-12}}</ref> !Revenue in US$ Millions (2016)<ref name=":1932" /> !Type !Category !Year Founded !Comments |- |1 |[[CVS Health|CVS]] |[[United States]] |14 |177,526 |Public |[[Health care|Health Care]] |1963 | |- |2 |[[Cardinal Health]] |United States |35 |121,546 |Public |[[Pharmeceutical|Pharmeceuticals]] |1971 | |- |3 |[[Microsoft]] |United States |69 |85,320 |Public |[[Software|Computer Software]] |1975 | |- |4 |[[Citigroup]]* |United States |74 |82,386 |Public |[[Banking]] |1812 ([[Citibank]]/[[Citigroup#Citicorp|Citicorp]]) | |- |5 |[[Morgan Stanley]]* |United States |267 |37,949 |Public |[[Finance]] |1935 ([[Morgan Stanley#The original Morgan Stanley (1935–1997)|The original Morgan Stanley]]) | |- |6 |[[TSMC]] |[[Taiwan]] |369 |29,388 |Public |[[Semiconductor]] |1987 | |- |7 |[[Facebook]] |United States |393 |27,638 |Public |[[Social networking service|Social Networking]] |2004 | |} <nowiki>*:</nowiki> <sub>Merger of different companies, at least one of which was founded by Harvard alumni.</sub>
=== Fortune 1000 (2017) === This list shows companies in [[Fortune 1000]] (only for companies within the [[United States|U.S.]]) founded or co-founded by Harvard alumni. The cut-off revenue for 2017 Fortune 1000 companies was $1,791M in 2016.<ref name=":1822">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/list/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2017: Who Made the List|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-11}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! !Company ! href="TSMC" |Fortune 1000 (2017)<ref name=":182">{{Cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/list/|title=Fortune 500 Companies 2017: Who Made the List|website=Fortune|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-11}}</ref> !Revenue in US$ Millions (2016)<ref name=":182" /> ! href="Taiwan" |Type !Category !Year Founded !Comments |- |1 | Hoffman / Philanthropist, founder of National Lampoon|work=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|access-date=2018-05-18|language=en}}</ref> | # [[Douglas Kenney]] (B.A)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://nypost.com/2018/01/25/the-tragic-life-and-death-of-a-national-lampoon-legend/|title=The tragic life and death of a ‘National Lampoon’ legend|date=2018-01-25|work=New York Post|access-date=2018-05-18|language=en-US}}</ref> # [[Henry Beard]] (B.A)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.simonandschuster.com/authors/Henry-Beard/1271644|title=Henry Beard|website=Simon & Schuster|language=en|access-date=2018-05-18}}</ref> # [[Robert Hoffman (businessman)|Robert Hoffman]] (B.A, M.B.A)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://obits.dallasnews.com/obituaries/dallasmorningnews/obituary.aspx?n=robert-kenneth-hoffman&pid=18962590|title=Robert Kenneth Hoffman's Obituary on Dallas Morning News|website=Dallas Morning News|access-date=2018-05-18}}</ref> |- |[[PlanetAll]] |Defunct | |Social Networking |1996 |2<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://venturefizz.com/blog/planetall-story-behind-world-s-first-social-networking-site|title=PlanetAll: The Story Behind the World’s First Social Networking Site|date=2016-08-17|work=VentureFizz|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en}}</ref> |<ol><li>Warren Adams (M.B.A)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=632024&privcapId=167087&previousCapId=1206164&previousTitle=Tiaxa%20Ltda.|title=Warren Adams: Executive Profile & Biography - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref></li><li>Brian Robertson (M.B.A)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pv-tech.org/news/amonix_ceo_brian_robertson_dies_in_light_aircraft_crash|title=Amonix CEO Brian Robertson dies in light aircraft crash|work=PV Tech|access-date=2018-05-09|language=en}}</ref> </li></ol> |- |[[Thinking Machines Corporation]] |Defunct | |Computer Hardware |1983 |2<ref name=":7">{{Cite news|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/19950915/2622.html|title=The Rise and Fall of Thinking Machines|date=1899-11-30|work=Inc.com|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref> | #Co-founder [[Sheryl Handler]] (M.S)<ref name=":7" /> |- |[[Viacom (original)|Viacom Inc.]] |Dissolved | |Media |1971 |1<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://successstory.com/companies/viacom|title=Viacom Profile, History, Founder, Founded, Ceo {{!}} Media Companies {{!}} SuccessStory|website=successstory.com|language=en|access-date=2018-05-18}}</ref> | # [[Sumner Redstone]] (B.A, J.D)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/sumner-redstone/|title=Sumner Redstone|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-05-18|language=en}}</ref> |}

[[File:Average and marginal product curves small.png|thumb]] In [[economics]] and in particular [[neoclassical economics]], the '''marginal product''' or '''marginal physical productivity''' of an input ([[factor of production]]) is the change in output resulting from employing one more unit of a particular input (for instance, the change in output when a firm's labor is increased from five to six units), assuming that the quantities of other inputs are kept constant.<ref>{{cite book|title =The Making of the Classical Theory of Economic Growth|last=Brewer |first=Anthony |url=https://books.google.com/?id=jBR4jmf75gYC&lpg=PA163&dq=Edward%20West%20diminishing&pg=PA163#v=onepage&q=Edward%20West%20diminishing&f=false |year=2010 |publisher =Routledge |isbn=0415486203 }}</ref>
The marginal product of a given input can be expressed<ref>{{cite book | last = Mukherjee | first = Sampat | last2 = Mukherjee | first2 = Mallinath | last3 = Ghose | first3 = Amitava | title = Microeconomics | publisher = Prentice-Hall of India | place = New Delhi | year = 2003 | isbn = 81-203-2318-1 }}</ref> as: :<math>MP = \frac{\Delta Y}{\Delta X}</math>
where <math>\Delta X</math> is the change in the firm's use of the input (conventionally a one-unit change) and <math>\Delta Y</math> is the change in quantity of output produced (resulting from the change in the input). Note that the quantity <math>Y</math> of the "product" is typically defined ignoring [[externalities|external costs and benefits]].
If the output and the input are infinitely divisible, so the marginal "units" are infinitesimal, the marginal product is the mathematical [[derivative]] of the [[production function]] with respect to that input. Suppose a firm's output ''Y'' is given by the production function: :<math>Y=F(K,L)</math>
where ''K'' and ''L'' are inputs to production (say, capital and labor). Then the marginal product of capital (''MPK'') and marginal product of labor (''MPL'') are given by:
:<math>MPK=\frac{\partial F}{\partial K}</math>
:<math>MPL=\frac{\partial F}{\partial L}</math>
In the "law" of [[diminishing returns|diminishing marginal returns]], the marginal product initially increases when more of an input (say labor) is employed, keeping the other input (say capital) constant. Here, labor is the variable input and capital is the fixed input (in a hypothetical two-inputs model). As more and more of variable input (labor) is employed, marginal product starts to fall. Finally, after a certain point, the marginal product becomes negative, implying that the additional unit of labor has ''decreased'' the output, rather than increasing it. The reason behind this is the diminishing [[marginal productivity of labor]].
The marginal product of labor is the slope of the [[total product]] curve, which is the production function plotted against labor usage for a fixed level of usage of the capital input.
In the neoclassical theory of [[perfect competition|competitive markets]], the [[marginal product of labor]] equals the [[real vs. nominal in economics|real]] wage. In aggregate models of perfect competition, in which a single good is produced and that good is used both in consumption and as a capital good, the [[marginal product of capital]] equals its [[rate of profit|rate of return]]. As was shown in the [[Cambridge capital controversy]], this proposition about the marginal product of capital cannot generally be sustained in multi-commodity models in which capital and consumption goods are distinguished.
'''Relationship of marginal product (MPP) with the total product (TPP)'''
The relationship can be explained in three phases- (1) Initially, as the quantity of variable input is increased, TPP rises at an increasing rate. In this phase, MPP also rises. (2) As more and more quantities of the variable inputs are employed, TPP increases at a diminishing rate. In this phase, MPP starts to fall. (3) When the TPP reaches its maximum, MPP is zero. Beyond this point, TPP starts to fall and MPP becomes negative.
== See also == {{div col}} *[[Marginal product of labor]] *[[Marginal product of capital]] *[[Marginal revenue productivity theory of wages]] *[[Production theory]] *[[Average product]] *[[Cost of production]] *[[Shadow price]] {{Marginal cost}}
== References == <references /> * {{cite book|title = Volkswirtschaft verstehen | last = Beck | first = Bernhard | url = https://books.google.com/?id=ZX2P5h7C7cUC&pg=PA66&dq=Grenzprodukt#v=onepage&q=Grenzprodukt&f=false | year = 2008 | isbn = 9783728132079 }} * {{Cite book | last = Rothbard | first = Murray N. | title = Classical Economics: An Austrian Perspective on the History of Economic Thought Volume II | publisher = Ludwig von Mises Institute | place = Auburn, Alabama | year = 1995 | url = http://library.mises.org/books/Murray%20N%20Rothbard/Classical%20Economics%20An%20Austrian%20Perspective%20on%20the%20History%20of%20Economic%20Thought,%20Volume%20II.pdf | isbn = 0-945466-48-X }}
[[Category:Production economics]] [[Category:Marginal concepts]]

{{ref improve|date=February 2014}} The '''Media-Analyse (ma)''' (''English'': '''Media Analysis (MA)''') by [[Media-Analyse AG]] (AGMA) is the largest annually conducted media analysis in [[Germany]] and the largest survey of media [[consumer behavior]] in Germany overall. It examines the total population as well as its subgroups. The survey occurs telephonically or with questionnaires given to a representative cross-section of the total population sample.
The yearly use of media is queried using dated surveys and daily routine studies. Initially, only the [[German language|German-speaking]] population of Germany was questioned, limited to those living in private households which was the main place of residence, and limited to those at least 14 years old. In 2008, the age limit was reduced to ten years old and [[European Union]] foreigners were incorporated. From 2010, “other foreigners” are also now questioned. This includes approximately 50,000 young people and adults who are chosen by random selection according to the ADM sampling system. They are subsequently questioned, some in person and some telephonically ([[Computer-assisted telephone interviewing|CATI]]). In the process, the subgroups are described based on their demographic features such as age, sex, occupation, income, religion, and community size.
The results of the media analysis are issued on behalf of AGMA by its subsidiary Media Micro Census. They have large practical relevance because they largely determine the booking behavior of the advertising industry. The MA thus indirectly determines the price a media provider can charge for advertising. It is hence regularly observed that some radio stations use a large part of their annual advertising budget during the survey period of the MA.
== MA Pressemedien == In ''MA Pressemedien'' (''English'': ''MA Press Media''), data is obtained on magazines, daily newspapers, supplements, city magazines, KONPRESS (denominational press; church newspapers), reading circles, and cinema. ''MA 2006 Pressemedien II'', published on July 26, 2006, noted 170 magazines. For this study, around 39,000 interviews were collectively carried out in two waves during a year (February 27, 2005 – February 4, 2006). The MA 2007 Pressemedien I appeared in January 2007.
From the Second Wave MA 2004 (September 2003 – February 2004) on, some changes in the survey method were carried out, one of which was the launch of the Title Split Method (division of the approximately 180 titles submitted into three otherwise identical questionnaire versions) as well as (first only in approximately 10% of the interviews) the [[Computer-assisted self interviewing|CASI]] method.
Through the introduction of the title split models, the reach of the magazines increases over the two waves by an average of 7% - though with clear deviations for individual titles up or down. A direct comparison of historical data is hence no longer justifiable because of methodological reasons.
As so-called “media currency”, the ''readers per issue (LpA)'' was established in the MA Pressemedien. It shows how many readers an issue of a certain magazine or newspaper has.
== MA Radio == In ''MA Radio'', the radio consumption for individual stations is queried. The MA Radio is conducted telephonically (the so-called CATI survey model), for which 58,011 people were questioned and appeared as ''MA 2006 Radio I'' on March 8, 2006.
As media currency, the so-called ''listeners per hour'' (for pre-determined hours) is reported as well as the ''average listeners per hour'' and the ''listeners per day''.
== MA Plakat == The first ''MA Plakat'' (''English'': ''MA Placard'') under the AGMA roof appeared on September 22, 2004.
On December 19, 2007 the MA 2007 Plakat was published. The coverage method of the MA Plakat was completely revised in 2007. The data is now based on a combined survey model, consisting of a CATI survey and a measurement method with a GPS receiver.
== Online Forschung AG (AGOF) == Since 2009, the collected ''Internet Facts'' of the ''Online Forschung AG (AGOF)'' (''English'': ''Online Research AG'') also fall under the methodological responsibility of the ''MA''.<ref>[http://www.agma-mmc.de/files/PMma09Online_I.pdf Pressemitteilung der AG-MA (pdf)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101223164524/http://www.agma-mmc.de/files/PMma09Online_I.pdf |date=2010-12-23 }}</ref>
AGOF records internet usage behavior with the Three Pillar Model: *First Pillar: Technical measurement (computer-level, units are individual visits and page views, obtained by [[IP Address]]) *Second Pillar: On-site surveys (Population is all internet users over 14 years old, reference to users in front of the computer, online questionnaires by pop-up window, query to place of use, time of use, sociodemographic data) *Third Pillar: Phone surveys (CATI, population-level)
== MA Intermedia == In the fall of each year, ''MA Intermedia'' also appears, in which information for magazines, newspapers, TV, and radio is summarized.
== General queries == In addition to media use, sociodemographic characteristics, leisure time behavior, and shopping behavior are collected. The questionnaire is largely identical to all MA studies (Press Media, Radio, Daily Newspaper).
== Licenses == The current data is only at the disposal of members of the ''Media-Analyse AG eV'' (publishing houses, radio stations, advertising agencies, advertisers, etc.). However, one can create a free individual query, e.g. about advertising departments of the publishing houses.
== Publication == The Media-Analyse appears twice per year for Pressemedien and Radio, and once per year for Tageszeitungen (''English'': Daily Newspapers) and Plakat. In [[Nordrhein-Westfalen]], the MA Radio is expanded for local radio stations through the E.M.A. NRW, while in [[Bavaria]], it is expanded through the Radio Analysis.
The first ''Leser-Analyse'' (''English'': ''Reader Analysis'') appeared in 1954, and thus AGMA celebrated its 50-year anniversary in 2004.
== Further analysis files == A whole series of further market and media studies of different providers are based on the MA-determined reach results, among them the TdW (Typologie der Wünsche (''English'': Typology of Desires) by Hubert Burda Media), VA (Verbraucher-Analyse (''English'': Consumer Analysis) by Axel Springer Publishers and Bauer Publishers), Communication Networks (Focus Magazine Publishers), MarkenProfile (''English'': BrandsProfile), VuMA, etc.
== References == All of the content of this article comes from the equivalent German-language Wikipedia article (see "Deutsch" link in the language list). Retrieved on February 25, 2014. The following references are cited by that German-language article:
<references />
[[Category:Surveys]] [[Category:Market research]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Nahum Manbar | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1946|04|18}} | birth_place = [[Givat Haim]], [[Mandatory Palestine]] | nationality = | other_names = | occupation = Businessman | years_active = | known_for = | notable_works = }} '''Nahum Manbar''' ({{lang-he|נחום מנבר}}, born April 18, 1946) is an [[Israel]]i businessman who was involved in arms trade with [[Iran]]. He was convicted in series of crimes against Israel's national security and served 14.5 years in prison, prior his release in October 2011.<ref name="saban">{{Cite news |title = A-G: Manbar will be released early from prison |work= Jpost|accessdate= 2011-10-31|date= 2011-10-31 |url= http://www.jpost.com/DiplomacyAndPolitics/Article.aspx?id=243833}}</ref>
==Early life== Manbar was born in [[kibbutz]] [[Givat Haim]] in 1946. His parents were among the founders of the kibbutz. At age 16, he was in the reserve squad of the Israeli national basketball team. He served as an officer in the [[Paratroopers Brigade]] after being conscripted into the [[Israel Defense Forces]] (IDF). He also served as an instructor at the IDF Officers' College. Manbar fought in both the [[Six-Day War]], [[War of Attrition]], and [[Yom Kippur War]]. During the Yom Kippur War, he saved the life of Hanoch Saar, who would later serve on his defense team.<ref name=bergman>Bergman, Ronen: ''The Secret War with Iran: The Clandestine Struggle Against the World's Most Dangerous Terrorist Power'' (2006)</ref>
==Career== After his military service, Manbar moved to [[Tel Aviv]] and opened up a series of businesses. His business ventures mostly ended with police investigations and indictments for crimes such as fraud, passing bad checks, and stealing checks from government employees. In 1984 he fled to the [[United Kingdom]] after being indicted for fraud, imposture, and theft, and was declared by Israel to be a fugitive from justice. He then began selling produce at the [[Covent Garden Market]] in [[London]], but soon left Britain and entered the arms trade. He set up weapons companies in [[Poland]] and [[France]]. During his career as an arms trader, he lived in France and [[Switzerland]] before settling in Poland and setting up his headquarters in [[Warsaw]]. Some of the weapons Manbar sold were purchased from the [[Polish Army]].<ref name=bergman/><ref name=greenberg1>{{Cite news | last = Greenberg | first = Joel | title = Israeli Held In Iran Traffic In Nerve Gas | work = New York Times | accessdate = 2008-03-08 | date = 1997-05-07 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9E04EFDE1130F934A35756C0A961958260 }}</ref> In 1994 he became a sponsor of [[Hapoel Jerusalem B.C.]]<ref name=guardia/>
Manbar sold arms to [[Iran]], establishing contacts in the Iranian Defense Ministry. According to the charges at his trial, Manbar made contact through an Iranian mediator with Majed Abasbur, then the head of the Iranian chemical weapons development project.<ref name=greenberg1/> A deal was signed between Manbar's Mana Investments International company and Iran's section 105B, represented by Abashur. Manbar initially sold Iran a small number of shoulder-launched anti-aircraft missiles. Through this deal, he became acquainted with Polish Defense Minister [[Florian Siwicki]]. Manbar later sold offensive weaponry such as [[T-54/55|T-55]] tanks purchased from the Polish military to Iran, explaining that "I would buy, say, T-55 tanks from the Polish army for $35,000 apiece, install some fire-control system I had bought from Israel for $20,000 apiece, and sell them to the Iranians for $200,000. The profits were fantastic".<ref name=bergman/>
Between 1992 and 1993, Manbar provided Iran with ingredients needed to make chemical weapons, equipment and expertise, and was paid $16 million by 1994 after providing elements of mustard gas and three types of nerve gas: [[Tabun (nerve agent)|Tabun]], [[Sarin]] and [[Soman]], and set up a plant in Poland to manufacture chemical weaponry for Iran. He obtained the raw materials necessary to make chemical weapons that he sold to Iran from [[China]] and [[Hungary]]. He also provided Iran with information and know-how to produce mustard gas. The indictment stated that he had not reported to Israeli intelligence about his contacts until August 1992, despite several meetings with members of the security forces. Despite committing himself to stop his illegal activity, he continued to do so for over a year. Manbar, however, claims that he informed Israeli authorities of his activities, and that his arms sales to Iran were approved by the Israeli Defense Ministry.<ref name="saban"/><ref name=bergman/> However, Manbar offered Israel information on military subjects, and also offered to use the high-level links he had with the Iranians to reveal the fate of [[Ron Arad (pilot)|Ron Arad]], exploiting [[Mossad]]'s desperation for any information on his fate. Manbar supplied the Mossad with a faked video and worthless leads.<ref name=bergman/> Manbar's activities, some of which were conducted in Britain, drew the attention of [[MI6]], which could not believe that an Israeli could be working so closely with Iran and concluded that Manbar was a Mossad agent trying to penetrate Iran's defense establishment.
Mossad began to investigate Manbar's dealings, and as part of the investigation , Mossad agents shadowed Abashur. On May 27, 1993, Manbar and Abashur met at the Marriott Hotel in [[Vienna]]. Abashur was tailed by two Mossad agents, and on his way there, he noticed he was being followed. When Abashur arrived, he told Manbar of the agents, and Manbar then confronted them and insinuated that he knew who they were, while Abashur, realizing that he had been discovered, left for an Iranian Embassy safe house. The two agents followed Abashur's car on a motorcycle, but due to heavy rain, they found it difficult to keep up with him, and as they emerged from an underpass, their motorcycle overturned. A car ran over the agents and killed them both. Their deaths reportedly increased the anger towards Manbar by the Israeli security services.<ref name=kibbutznik>{{Cite news | last = Melman | first = Yossi | title = The Israeli kibbutznik who dealt weapons to Iran | work = Haaretz | accessdate = December 25, 2013 | date = October 31, 2011 | url = http://www.haaretz.com/blogs/2.294/the-israeli-kibbutznik-who-dealt-weapons-to-iran-1.393001}}</ref><ref name=bergman/>
In 1994, he was accused by the US government of selling components for [[mustard gas]] and [[nerve gas]] to Iran in defiance of a US embargo<ref name=guardia>{{Cite news | last = La Guardia | first = Anton | title = Iran's 'nerve gas trader' disappears | work = The Telegraph | accessdate = 2008-03-09 | date = 1997-04-15 | url = https://www.telegraph.co.uk/htmlContent.jhtml?html=/archive/1997/04/15/wirn15.html }}</ref> and was barred from entering the United States.<ref name=greenberg2>{{Cite news | last = Greenberg | first = Joel | title = Israeli Linked To Iran Arms Ordered Jailed | work = New York Times | accessdate = 2008-03-08 | date = 1997-04-18 | url = https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A06E4DC103FF93BA25757C0A961958260 }}</ref>
In 1997, Deputy Attorney-General for Security Affairs Dvorah Chen concluded that she could prosecute Manbar for harming the security of the state and aiding the enemy in war against Israel. Mossad officials managed to persuade a Polish businessman who served as his right-hand man to agree to testify against him. On March 27, 1997, Manbar arrived in Israel to watch Hapoel Jerusalem compete for the State Cup. Upon arrival, he was arrested by [[Shin Bet]] and the Serious Crimes Unit of the [[Israel Police]]. His detention was initially placed under a [[gag order]], and was cleared for publication several weeks later. In May he was indicted and his case was brought before the [[Israeli judicial system|Tel Aviv District Court]].<ref name=greenberg2/>
==Trial== Manbar's trial began on 15 May. The trial was held behind closed doors, and much of the testimony was classified. His defense was based on the case that he did not act alone, and that Israeli businessmen were being allowed to sell weapons to Iran by the security authorities.<ref name=bergman/>
On July 16, 1998, he was unanimously convicted of collaboration with an enemy and providing information to an enemy. The court rejected his claims for lack of [[Intention (criminal law)|criminal intent]] and established that he had known about Abbasfour's senior position. He was sentenced to 16 years in prison. He served his sentence at Nitzan Prison in [[Ramla]],<ref name="saban">{{Cite news |last= Saban |first= Itzik |title= Israeli convicted of aiding Iran up for parole |work= Ynetnews |accessdate= 2008-03-08 |date= 2007-04-06 |url= http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3408320,00.html}}</ref> and later at HaSharon Prison at the Hadarim Interchange.
Manbar appealed to the [[Supreme Court of Israel]] but his appeal was denied on December 5, 2000. In 2007 applied a request for parole, having been described as a well-behaved prisoner.<ref name="saban"/> However, the Shin Bet and Mossad objected,<ref name=luvitch>{{Cite news|last= Luvitch|first= Vered|title= State against paroling Enemy of State|work= Ynetnews|accessdate= 2008-03-09|date= 2007-10-29|url= http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3465489,00.html}}</ref> and in early 2008 his request was denied by the Jerusalem District Court.<ref name=yarkoni>{{Cite news | last = Yarkoni | first = Yoram | title = Enemy of the State's parole denied | work = Ynetnews | accessdate = 2008-03-08 | date = 2008-01-16 | url = http://www.ynet.co.il/english/articles/0,7340,L-3494877,00.html }}</ref> It was argued that he might be recruited by Iran.<ref name=ben-zur>{{Cite news | last = Ben-Zur | first = Raanan | title = ‘Iran may recruit Israeli treason convict if he is freed’ | work = Ynetnews | accessdate = 2008-03-09 | date = 2007-05-07 | url = http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3421771,00.html }}</ref>
===Controversy=== The trial was laden with controversy. Manbar's attorney, Amnon Zichroni, alleged that Prime Minister [[Benjamin Netanyahu]] had contacted the presiding judge in the case, Amnon Straschnov, to lobby for a harsh sentence for Manbar.<ref name=cnn>{{Cite news | title = Israel gripped by swirl surrounding treason trial | work = CNN.com | accessdate = 2008-03-08 | date = 1998-07-16 | url = http://www.cnn.com/WORLD/meast/9807/16/israel.treason/ }}</ref> Netanyahu's office denied the allegations.<ref name=kennedy>{{Cite news | last = Kennedy | first = Duncan | title = Sex scandal in Israel treason trial | work = BBC | accessdate = 2008-03-08 | date = 1998-07-16 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/middle_east/133261.stm }}</ref> Zichroni further alleged that a female member of his defense team, attorney Pninat Yanai, passed along privileged information about Manbar to Straschnov—with whom, Zichroni claimed, she was having a sexual affair.<ref name=cnn/> Yanai, who had been fired from her duties and was also a friend of Netanyahu's spokesman, denied those allegations as well.<ref name=kennedy/>
Ex-[[Mossad]] agent [[Victor Ostrovsky]] pointed out that Manbar was given a small pool of lawyers to choose from and that the trial was conducted behind closed doors. He also said Manbar had contacts in the Israeli security services and that several deals with Iran had been made in the past.<ref name=ostrovsky>{{Cite journal | pages = 55–56, 62 | last = Ostrovsky | first = Victor | title = What Israel’s Top-Secret Manbar Trial Reveals About Extensive, Ongoing Israeli Arms Dealing With Iran | journal = Washington Report on Middle East Affairs | accessdate = 2008-03-08 | date = September 1998 | url = http://www.washington-report.org/backissues/0998/9809055.html }}</ref>
Others also considered it a link in a chain of shady deals between Israel and Iran that goes back to the [[Iran-Contra affair]], and that he had taken the fall for the Israeli military and security industry.<ref name=arabic>{{Cite news |title = Manbar: victim of Israeli-Iranian covert relations |work = Arabic News |accessdate = 2008-03-08 |date = 1998-07-16 |url = http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/980716/1998071615.html |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080203141354/http://www.arabicnews.com/ansub/Daily/Day/980716/1998071615.html |archivedate = February 3, 2008 |df = mdy-all }}</ref>
==Personal life== In France, Manbar met a French woman, Francine. They married April 21. 1992 and had a son.
Francine gave the Mossad information on her previous husband's dealings with the Condor Argentine Missile Program before her marriage.<ref name=kibbutznik/> On March 2. 2010 the couple obtained a divorce (Tel Aviv District Family Court DMC 13120-07).
In 2003, while still in prison, Manbar was declared bankrupt, and appointed a [[Trustee in bankruptcy|trustee]].<ref>http://elyon1.court.gov.il/files/12/380/093/o03/12093380.o03.htm</ref>
==See also== *[[Iran–Israel relations]] *[[Iran and weapons of mass destruction]]
==References== {{reflist|2}}

{{lead too short|date=August 2012}} {{Infobox person |name = Nicolae Malaxa |image = Malaxa.jpg |image_size = 150px |caption = |birth_name = |birth_date = {{birth-date|22 December 1884}} |birth_place = [[Huşi]], [[Romania]] |death_date = {{death-date|1965}} |death_place = [[New Jersey]], [[United States]] |death_cause = |nationality = [[Romania]]n |other_names = |known_for = |education = |occupation = [[Engineer]]
[[Industrialist]] |parents = |relatives = |footnotes = }} '''Nicolae Malaxa''' ({{OldStyleDate|22 December|1884|10 December}} – 1965) was a [[Romania]]n engineer and industrialist. ==Biography== Born in a family of [[Aromanians|Aromanian]] origins in [[Huşi]], Malaxa studied engineering in [[Iaşi]] (at the [[University of Iaşi]]) and [[Karlsruhe]] (at the [[Karlsruhe University of Applied Sciences|Polytechnic University]]). Late in his life, [[Petre Pandrea]], a Romanian intellectual who was for long a member of the [[Romanian Communist Party|Communist Party]] and later became a victim of the [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]], wrote a memoir which, in part, dealt with Malaxa's biography, recording it with a dose of hostility. In it, he indicated that Malaxa's father died a young man, and that Nicolae was kept in university with money earned by his mother and sister.Pandrea, p. 65. Pandrea, who called Malaxa "a mama's boy" and argued that this had shaped his character, also noted that, after graduation and contrary to his family's wishes, the engineer married a divorcée (who had been married to one of his early business partners). In time, he claimed, tensions grew between the two Malaxas, after the "[[Puritan]]" Nicolae came to resent his "frivolous" wife.Pandrea, p. 67. Malaxa joined the [[Căile Ferate Române|Romanian Railways Company]] as a constructions engineer. Petre Pandrea implied that this went against procedure, and was the result of Nicolae Malaxa having befriended Chairman Alexandru Cottescu. The same source indicated that Malaxa continued to engage in business ventures, and that, upon the end of [[World War I]] and the [[Romanian Campaign (World War I)|Romanian Campaign]], he was living in Iaşi and managing a grape-selling business. In 1918-1919, he quit his job at the Company and started a new business dealing with [[rolling stock]] maintenance — the venture was instantly successful, a fact which Pandrea attributed to the infrastructure's decay under the previous occupation by the [[Central Powers]].Pandrea, pp. 65-66. Thus, Malaxa revitalized rail vehicles left into disrepair, which he sold back to the state at ten times the investment.Pandrea, p. 66. According to ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', Malaxa "parlayed a shoestring into a chain of arms factories and a partnership in Rumania's largest iron works"."New Order", in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', February 10, 1940. By the end of the 1930s, the Malaxa factories were mass-producing [[steam locomotive]]s, [[diesel locomotives]], [[trainset]]s, rolling stock, steel [[piping|pipe]]s, and were one of the biggest industrial groups in [[Balkans|Southeastern Europe]], and the main provider of equipment for the Romanian Railways during the period. In several of his locomotive designs, Malaxa used innovative solutions (in locomotive design — those developed in by [[George Constantinescu]] on the basis of his ''[[theory of sonics]]''; in factory design — in collaboration with [[Horia Creangă]]).{{ro icon}} Anca Vlada, "Nicolae Malaxa, un industriaş vizionar" ("Nicolae Malaxa, a Visionary Industrialist"), in ''[[Curierul Naţional]]'', August 11, 2005. Owning much of Romania's steel industry through his strong presence in [[Reşiţa]],Nicole Jordan, ''The Popular Front and Central Europe: The Dilemmas of French Impotence, 1918-1940'', [[Cambridge University Press]], Cambridge, 1992, p. 127, {{ISBN|0-521-52242-0}}. he was chairman of the [[Ford Motor Company]]'s Romanian section, and arguably the richest man in Romania at the time."Malaxa Wins Permanent Home in U.S.", in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', September 9, 1958. Malaxa was close to the [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian]] [[King of Romania|King]] [[Carol II of Romania|Carol II]]. Together with [[Aristide Blank]] and [[Max Auschnitt]], he was one of the major businessmen present in the king's ''[[Camarilla (history)|camarilla]]'' (''see [[National Renaissance Front]]'');"«God Help Your Majesty»", in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'', September 16, 1940.Veiga, p. 128. such political connections also implied that his success was partly ensured by preferential deals agreed with the state, and in some cases by the placement of inferior products on a [[captive market]].Veiga, pp. 212-213. According to Pandrea, Malaxa had made a habit of manipulating state officials into granting him preferential credits, which explained his interest in supporting Carol's moves. Reportedly, Malaxa and his wife were especially close to the king's mistress, [[Elena Lupescu]], and even became related through marriage (after Lupescu's nephew, an engineer, married the niece of Malaxa's wife).Pandrea, pp. 66-67. Around 1939, Carol's son [[Michael I of Romania|Michael]] was rumored to be in a relationship with Lulu Malaxa (Nicolae's daughter)."Carol Lunches with Michael's Girlfriend, Pretty Commoner", in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', July 1, 1939. Petre Pandrea also alleged that, soon after turning 17, the virgin Lulu had been raped by Carol on board his ''Luceafărul'' [[yacht]] — before her father decided to intervene, remove her from the circle of friends, and send her to study in [[Paris]]. Pandrea also claimed that this was the origin of the notorious conflict between the engineer and Auschnitt, alleging that the latter's wife, was Carol's third mistress and resented Lulu's apparent success. He also claimed that Elena Lupescu was cheating on the king with his secretary [[Ernest Urdăreanu]], who was also an important figure of the ''camarilla'' and who kept close contacts with the Malaxas. Unlike most other large industries in the country, Malaxa's was not tied to [[United Kingdom|British]], [[France|French]] or [[First Republic of Czechoslovakia|Czechoslovak]] interests. Instead, Nicolae Malaxa maintained business links with [[Nazi Germany]] as early as 1935. At a time when Nazi Germany was gaining more influence in Romania, Nicolae Malaxa collaborated with [[Hermann Göring]] in confiscating the assets of the [[History of the Jews in Romania|Jewish]] Auschnitt (who had been arrested and prosecuted on false charges in September 1939),Veiga, pp. 267, 278. and subsequently placed his industrial empire in the service of the ''[[Reichswerke Hermann Göring|Reichswerke]]'' during [[World War II]]."Nazis Get Steel Works", in ''[[The New York Times]]'', February 22, 1941.Veiga, p. 267. Just after Carol fell from power in 1940, Malaxa was briefly imprisoned on charges that he had resorted to [[extortion]] in previous years. Probably sympathizing with [[Nazism|Nazi]] ideology, he had financed the activities of the Romanian [[far right]] [[Iron Guard]] organization as early as the mid-1930s,Veiga, p. 222. and especially throughout the [[National Legionary State]] the latter established.Veiga, p. 306. During the [[Legionnaires' Rebellion and Bucharest Pogrom|Rebellion and Pogrom]] it provoked in January 1941, the Guard made use of arms manufactured by Malaxa, as well of his house (turned into a citadel and attacked by the [[Romanian Army]])"Rumania Tries Arms Maker in Guard Revolt", in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', January 29, 1941. — he was consequently put on trial by [[Ion Antonescu]]'s government. In February 1945, several months after the [[King Michael Coup]] which toppled Antonescu, and following the start of [[Soviet occupation of Romania|Soviet occupation]], his Bucharest factories were at the center of mysterious and violent events.R. J. Crampton, ''Eastern Europe in the Twentieth Century'', [[Routledge]], London, 1994, p. 229, {{ISBN|0-415-05346-3}}. At the time, independent [[Prime Minister of Romania|Premier]] [[Nicolae Rădescu]] had come into conflict with the rising [[Romanian Communist Party]], and his frequent speeches to his supporters were disrupted by organized workers. This occurred in Malaxa's plant, and the incident ended with shots being fired and several people killed. The Communist Party claimed that they had been targeted by the Army, acting on orders from Rădescu, despite the fact that bullets recovered from the bodies were not of the kind used by the military. Aggravated by another of Rădescu's addresses, in which he deemed Communists "foreigners without God or a nation", the crisis ended with the appointment of a new cabinet endorsed by the Communist Party and the [[Soviet Union]] and presided by [[Ploughmen's Front]] leader [[Petru Groza]]. Malaxa used his opportunity to flee after being sent on an economic mission by King Michael, and settled in [[New York City]], where his family joined him after being expelled by the Groza government. Malaxa and his son Constantin (1922–1999) had their Romanian citizenship revoked in by the [[Communist Romania|Communist regime]] in 1948."Rumanians Lose Citizenship", in ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 6, 1948. In May of that year, he met with the ousted Nicolae Rădescu, and financed him money to start issuing an [[Anti-communism|anti-communist]] magazine titled ''Luceafărul'' (of which philosopher [[Mircea Eliade]] was editor).[[Mircea Eliade]], ''Autobiography'', [[University of Chicago Press]], Chicago, 1990, p. 126, {{ISBN|0-226-20411-1}}. Alongside accusations involving his endorsement of the Iron Guard, it was alleged that he had been collaborating with the [[Romanian Communist Party]] during his last years in Romania. In 1955, while Malaxa was visiting [[Argentina]], the [[Immigration and Naturalization Service]] briefly revoked his reentry permit."Romania's 'Ford' Wins Conditional Reentry to U.S.", in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', December 17, 1955. Both charges were again voiced by [[United States Democratic Party|Democratic Party]] politicians during [[Richard Nixon]]'s [[California gubernatorial election, 1962|1962 electoral campaign]] for [[Governor of California|Governor]] in [[California]], after focus was placed on the friendship and business connections between Nixon and Malaxa."Nixon Is Accused of Aid to Ex-Nazi", in ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 7, 1962. A government investigation dismissed the accusations,"Nixon-Malaxa Link Denied by Attorney", in ''[[The New York Times]]'', October 10, 1962. but, in 1979, his pro-Nazi past was again investigated by ''[[The Washington Post]]'' (which claimed that high-ranking American officials close to Malaxa had been involved in a cover-up).[[Jack Anderson (columnist)|Jack Anderson]], "Nixon Helped Rich Nazi Stay in U.S.", in ''[[The Washington Post]]'', November 16, 1979. Suspicions regarding Malaxa's alleged [[communism]], dismissed early in the era of [[McCarthyism]] by Rădescu,"Malaxa Record Cited", in ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 1, 1952. were investigated in 1958 by the [[United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration, Border Security, and Claims|United States House Judiciary Subcommittee on Immigration]], and centered on rich gifts he had sent to Communist leaders such as [[Ana Pauker]] — Malaxa defended himself by arguing that these had been sent in order to ensure his family's safe passage into America. Having apparently never applied for American citizenship, Malaxa died at his residence in [[New Jersey]]. ==See also== *''[[Malaxa (car)|Malaxa]]'', the car developed at Malaxa's plant *''[[FAUR]]'', the later name of Malaxa's rolling stock plant *''[[I.O.R.]]'', optics company co-founded by Malaxa ==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}} ==References== *[[Petre Pandrea]], "Cronică valahă cu inginerul Malaxa" ("Wallachian Chronicle with Engineer Malaxa"), in ''[[Magazin Istoric]]'', May 2002. *Francisco Veiga, ''Istoria Gărzii de Fier, 1919-1941: Mistica ultranaţionalismului'' ("History of the Iron Guard, 1919-1941: The Mistique of Ultra-Nationalism"), Bucharest, [[Humanitas publishing house|Humanitas]], 1993 (Romanian-language version of the 1989 Spanish edition ''La mística del ultranacionalismo (Historia de la Guardia de Hierro) Rumania, 1919–1941'', Bellaterra, Publicacions de la [[Universitat Autònoma de Barcelona]], {{ISBN|84-7488-497-7}}). {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Malaxa, Nicolae}} [[Category:1884 births]] [[Category:1965 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century Romanian people]] [[Category:Romanian businesspeople]] [[Category:Romanian engineers]] [[Category:Romanian industrialists]] [[Category:Romanian fascists]] [[Category:Romanian collaborators with Nazi Germany]] [[Category:Romanian defectors]] [[Category:Anti-communism in the United States]] [[Category:Richard Nixon]] [[Category:Alexandru Ioan Cuza University alumni]] [[Category:Karlsruhe Institute of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Romanian people of Greek descent]] [[Category:Romanian expatriates in the United States]] [[Category:People from Huși]]

'''Operational continuity''' refers to the ability of a system to continue working despite damages, losses or critical events. In the Human Resources and Organizational domain, including IT, it implies the need to determine the level of [[Resilience_(organizational)|resilience]] of the system, its ability to recover after an event, and build a system that resists to external and internal events or is able to recover after an event without losing its external [[performance management]] capability. Organizational Continuity is achieved only with specific corporate planning.<ref>Argenti, John (1974). Systematic Corporate Planning. Wiley.</ref> In the material domain, it determines the need to adopt redundant systems, performance monitoring systems, and can even imply the practice to cannibalize or to remove serviceable assemblies, sub-assemblies or components from a repairable or serviceable item of equipment in order to install them on another, in order to keep the external system performance active.<ref>North Atlantic Treaty Organization, Nato Standardization Agency AAP-6 - Glossary of terms and definitions, p 188.</ref> Operational continuity may be referred to single systems, single individuals, up to teams or entire complex systems such as IT infrastructures, implying the ability of an organization or system to continue to provide its mission.
==See also== * [[Business continuity]] * [[Disaster response]] * [[Emergency management]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/Legacy/SP/nistspecialpublication800-34r1.pdf National Institute of Science and Technology (NIST) Special Publication 800-34: Contingency Planning Guide for Information Technology Systems] * [https://drii.org/resources/professionalpractices/EN The Professional Practices for Business Continuity Management, Disaster Recovery Institute International (DRI), 2017.]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2016}} '''Patrick Hally''' (1866 – 21 July 1938) was a Catholic bootmaker turned politician in [[Dunedin]] at the turn of the twentieth century. He was one of the three original conciliation commissioners appointed under the [[Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1894|Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act]] in 1909.
==Early life== Hally was born in 1866 in Dunedin, the eldest son of John Hally. He was educated locally at the Christian Brothers' School before leaving to start an apprenticeship in the boot making trade. In 1891 he established his own shoemaking business in [[George Street, Dunedin]].<ref name="McKee" >{{cite book |chapter-url= http://nzetc.victoria.ac.nz/tm/scholarly/tei-Cyc04Cycl-t1-body1-d2-d8.html |title=[[The Cyclopedia of New Zealand]] |last= | first= |chapter=Otago & Southland Provincial Districts |publisher= | editor-first= Arthur |editor-last= McKee |editor-link=Arthur McKee |accessdate=29 February 2016 |year=1905 |date= }}</ref>
==Political career== Hally was involved in local politics much of his life. He was a Labour movement sympathiser, and in 1899 became the president of the New Zealand Federal Tailoresses' Union and later was a [[Dunedin City Council]]lor, elected to represent the Bell Ward in 1902.<ref name="McKee" /> He was a prominent member of the union-based Workers' Political Committee, an [[Otago]]-based organisation tasked with choosing political candidates to represent workers politically.<ref>{{cite journal| last = Boyd| first = Judi| last2 = Olssen| first2 = Erik| date = 1988| title = The Skilled Workers: Journeymen and Masters in Caversham, 1880-1914| url = http://www.nzjh.auckland.ac.nz/docs/1988/NZJH_22_2_03.pdf| journal = New Zealand Journal of History| publisher = Auckland University Press| volume = 22| issue = 2| pages = 129| access-date= 29 February 2016}}</ref> Hally was also a member of the Dunedin Catholic Literary Society.
In 1901 Hally contested the [[Caversham by-election, 1901|Caversham by-election]] under a Labour banner. In a six-way contest he came third with a respectable 1,120 votes (nearly a quarter of the total vote) losing to the [[New Zealand Liberal Party|Liberal Party]]'s candidate [[Thomas Sidey]].<ref name="The Caversham By-election">{{cite news |title=The Caversham By-election |url= http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=MEX19011220.2.18 |accessdate=2 January 2016 | work=[[The Marlborough Express]] | volume=XXXV | issue=295 |date=20 December 1901 |page=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Election Notices |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=ESD19011212.2.44.5 |accessdate=7 January 2016 |work=[[Evening Star (Dunedin)|Evening Star]] |issue=11729 |date=12 December 1901 |page=5}}</ref>
Hally was one of the three original conciliation commissioners appointed under the [[Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1894|Industrial Conciliation and Arbitration Act]] introduced in 1908. He was appointed in 1909 and served alongside T. Harle Giles and James Richard Triggs.<ref name="Herald obit">{{cite news |title=Long service |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&cl=search&d=NZH19380722.2.125 |accessdate=5 March 2016 |work=[[The New Zealand Herald]] |volume=LXXV |issue=23096 |date=22 July 1938 |page=13}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=House and stables, 42 Innes Road, Christchurch |url=http://christchurchcitylibraries.com/Heritage/Photos/disc3/IMG0012.asp |publisher=[[Christchurch City Libraries]] |accessdate=5 March 2016}}</ref> Hally was a commissioner until 1916, and again from 1922 until 13 September 1936.<ref name="Herald obit" />
==Family and death== Hally's first wife died in 1907.<ref>{{cite news |title=Deaths |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=ODT19070218.2.32 |accessdate=5 March 2016 |work=[[Otago Daily Times]] |issue=13830 |date=18 February 1907 |page=4}}</ref> He married a second time. He lost a son in [[World War I]]. In 1936, Hally retired for health reasons. After having been ill for several weeks, he died in Auckland on 21 July 1938. He was survived by his wife and two sons.<ref>{{cite news |title=Obituary |url=http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=CHP19380722.2.122 |accessdate=5 March 2016 |work=[[The Press]] | volume=LXXIV |issue=22460 |date=22 July 1938 |page=18}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hally, Patrick}} [[Category:1866 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:Dunedin City Councillors]] [[Category:New Zealand businesspeople]] [[Category:New Zealand trade unionists]]

{{Infobox academic | name = Peter van den Bossche | birth_date = 1959 | birth_place = [[Belgium]] | nationality = Belgian | residence = [[Switzerland]] | occupation = Professor of [[Law]]
[[University of Bern]],
[[World Trade Institute]] | alma_mater = [[European University Institute]] | discipline = [[Law]] | sub_discipline = [[International economic law|International Economic Law]]
[[International Trade Law]]
[[International investment agreement|International Investment Law]] | influenced = | footnotes = }} '''Peter van den Bossche''' (born 1959) is a professor of [[international economic law]] at the [[University of Bern]] ([[World Trade Institute]]).{{cite web |title=Peter van den Bossche Ordentlicher Professor für Internationales Wirtschaftsrecht |url= http://www.unibe.ch/aktuell/medien/media_relations/archiv/personalia_archiv/2016/personalia_2016/neuanstellungen_februar_juli_2016/peter_van_den_bossche/index_ger.html | website=www.unibe.ch | accessdate=4 October 2018|date= 2016-07-05 }} In 2018 he was elected president of the Society of International Economic Law (SIEL).{{cite web |title=SIEL Office Bearers as of 2018 Annual General Meeting |url=http://www.sielnet.org/page-1824535 |website=www.sielnet.org |accessdate=4 October 2018}}{{cite web |title=Colloquium on Restoring Trust in Trade in honour of Peter van den Bossche |url=http://www.sielnet.org/News/6390568 |website=www.sielnet.org |accessdate=4 October 2018}}{{cite web |title=Society of International Economic Law elects Peter van den Bossche president| url=https://www.wti.org/institute/news/518/society-of-international-economic-law-elects-peter-van-den-bossche-president/ | website=www.wti.org | accessdate=4 October 2018}} He served as a judge on the [[Dispute settlement in the World Trade Organization#WTO Appellate Body|Appelate Body]] of the [[World Trade Organization]] (WTO) from 2009-2017, following nomination by the [[European Union]] and appointment and re-appointment by the [[Member states of the World Trade Organization]].{{cite web |title=Belg wordt rechter bij Wereldhandelsorganisatie, ''De Morgen'' 29 mei 2009. |url=http://www.demorgen.be/buitenland/belg-wordt-rechter-bij-wereldhandelsorganisatie-ba8dcc01| accessdate=4 October 2018}}{{cite web | title = Peter van den Bossche appointed as one of the seven members of the Dispute Settlement Body of the World Trade Organisation (WTO), ''Kingdom of Belgium, Foreign Affairs Newsroom'' |url=https://diplomatie.belgium.be/en/Newsroom/news/press_releases/foreign_affairs/2009/juny/ni_190609_van_den_bossche_nieuw_lid_wto | accessdate=4 October 2018|date=2009-06-19 }}{{cite web |title=Appellate Body Members |url=https://www.wto.org/english/tratop_e/dispu_e/ab_members_bio_e.htm |website=www.wto.org |publisher=World Trade Organization |accessdate=4 October 2018}} In December 2013 his appointment was renewed.[http://www.maastrichtuniversity.nl/web/Main1/SiteWide/SiteWide11/PeterVanDenBosscheHerbenoemdAlsRechterBijWereldhandelsorganisatie.htm Peter van den Bossche herbenoemd als rechter bij Wereldhandelsorganisatie], ''[[Universiteit Maastricht]] 2 december 2013'' With the end of his formal appointment at the end of 2017, US-driven delays in appointing his replacement alongside US blocking of other key [[World Trade Organization|WTO]] vacancies has meant a growing crisis for the [[WTO]]-based multilateral trading system.{{cite news |last1=Jim Brunsden and Alan Beattie |title=EU’s top trade official warns on Trump impact on WTO US stance risks ‘killing the WTO from inside’, official says |url=https://www.ft.com/content/f6a7768c-b029-11e7-aab9-abaa44b1e130 |accessdate=4 October 2018 |publisher=Financial Times |date=16 October 2017}}{{cite news |last1=Baschuk |first1=Bryce |title=U.S. Demands Exacerbate WTO Dispute Body Turmoil |url=https://www.bna.com/us-demands-exacerbate-n57982087682/ |accessdate=4 October 2018 |work=International Trade Daily |publisher=Bloomberg |date=11 September 2017}} The election of van den Bossche (an outgoing WTO judge) as SIEL president is considered by some a sign of both defiance to economic nationalism and support for the [[WTO|rules-based multilateral system]].{{cite web |title=Peter van Den Bossche |url=https://www.coleurope.eu/whoswho/person/peter.van-den-bossche |website=www.coleurope.eu |publisher=College of Europe |accessdate=16 October 2018}} Prior to his appointment at the University of Bern, he was employed at the Faculty of Law of [[Maastricht University]] (1992-2016), where he was senior lecturer from 1993-2001, and [[:nl: Hoogleraar|Professor]] of [[International economic law]] from 2001-2016. From 2005-2009 he was head of department of the Department of International and European Law. In 2007 he founded the Institute for Globalization and International Regulation. From 1990 to 1992, he worked as référendaire at the [[European Court of Justice]] in [[Luxembourg]] and, from 1997 to 2001, as senior legal advisor to the WTO Appellate Body in Geneva. He serves on the Advisory Board of several academic law journals: ''Journal of World Investment and Trade''; ''Journal of International Economic Law''; and ''Revista Latinoamericana de Derecho Comercial Internacional''. He is also on the advisory board for the ''WTO Chairs Programme'' of the World Trade Organization. Through its various editions, his book ''The Law and Policy of the World Trade Organization'' has become a standard reference on international trade law and the dispute settlement mechanism.{{cite journal |last1=Trachtman |first1=Joel P. |title=The Law and Policy of the World Trade Organization: Text, Cases and Materials. Book Review |journal=Journal of International Economic Law |date=16 January 2006 |volume=9 |issue=1 |pages=233–235 |doi=10.1093/jiel/jgi053 |url=https://academic.oup.com/jiel/article-abstract/9/1/233/847594?redirectedFrom=PDF |accessdate=4 October 2018}} (See [[International Trade Law#References|International Trade Law]].) He received a PhD from the [[European University Institute]] in [[Florence]] (1990). He also holds a Licence en Droit magna cum laude from the [[University of Antwerp]] and an LL.M. from the [[University of Michigan]] Law School. == Books == * Charnovitz, Steve, Debra P. Steger, and Peter van den Bossche, eds., ''Law in the service of human dignity," Cambridge University Press, 2005, {{ISBN|9781139448420}}, 9781139448420; * van den Bossche, Peter, ''The Law and Policy of the World Trade Organization,'' Cambridge University Press, 2008, {{ISBN|9780521898904}}, 9780521898900, 9780521727594, 9780521727596; *Schneider, Hildegard, and Peter van den Bossche, eds. ''Protection of cultural diversity from a European and international perspective,'' Vol. 9. Intersentia Uitgevers NV, 2008. {{ISBN|9789050958646}},9050958648; *van den Bossche, Peter, and Denise Prévost, ''Essentials of WTO law, '' Cambridge University Press, 2016, {{ISBN|9781107035836}}, 978110703583X, 9781107638938, 9781107638933; *van den Bossche, Peter, Leo Henry, and Werner Zdouc. ''The Law and Policy of the World Trade Organization: Text, Cases and Materials, '' Cambridge University Press, 2017, {{ISBN|9781107694293}},971107694299. == References == {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:van den Bossche, Peter}} [[Category:European University Institute alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Maastricht University faculty]] [[Category:University of Michigan Law School alumni]] [[Category:University of Bern faculty]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:World Trade Organization people]] [[Category:International law scholars]] [[Category:International trade law]] [[Category:University of Antwerp alumni]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2015}} [[File:Piet Klijnveld (1874-1945).jpg|thumb|Piet Klijnveld (1874-1945)]] '''Pieter 'Piet' Klijnveld''' (16 August 1874 – 9 February 1945)<ref name="gen">[http://www.familysearch.org/ Genealogical data from Familysearch.org]</ref> was a [[Netherlands|Dutch]] accountant who started a practice that after several mergers would grow into the international accounting firm [[KPMG]].
== Life and career == Pieter Klijnveld was born on 16 August 1874 in [[Amsterdam]] in the Netherlands. He was the son of Pieter Klijnveld Sr. and Maria Christina Klijnveld. He married Cristina Johanna Royaards on 2 August 1906 in Amsterdam.<ref name="gen"/>
After working at the Amsterdam office of the Twentsche Bank (a precursor of [[ABN Amro]]), he opened a small accountancy practice in 1917 in his home on the Viottastraat. It would take a few years before a second office was in use on the Tesselschadestraat. Amsterdam was a bustling trade and investment hub for European and Asian industrialists. Many foreign enterprises, including royalty, governments, and even the [[Bank of England]], traded extensively in the Netherlands at the time, making it an active market for financiers as well as importers and exporters of virtually everything.
Klijnveld became the chief accountant to many of these emerging businesses. To meet the demands of his growing client roster, he teamed up with a local tax firm called Meijburg & Company. One of these accountants was Jaap Kraayenhof, who joined Klynveld and eventually become senior partner of the Dutch firm "Klijnveld Kraayenhof & Co.", abroad usually written as [[Klynveld Kraayenhof & Co.]] (KKC).
Klijnveld died just before the liberation of the Netherlands in 1945 and his wife died in September 1947. They had an art collection that included amongst others works by [[Piet Mondriaan]].<ref>[http://www.glerum.nl/catalogus.php?id=151&lang=en Auctioneer information]</ref>
== Legacy == Specializing in banking and exporting, KKC kept its name and independence by serving Dutch clients who were expanding throughout Europe and South America. In 1979, Klynveld Main Goerdeler (KMG) was formed with the merger of Klynveld Kraayenhof & Company, Deutsche Treuhand-Gesellschaft (DTG), and McLintock Main Lafrentz to create a strong European-based international firm.
In 1987, KMG and Peat Marwick International (PMI) combined in the first mega-merger of large accounting firms forming [[KPMG]].
==Main source== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20081203043747/http://kpmghu.lcc.ch/dbfetch/52616e646f6d4956c247e50a674f62a32f0d015479d0165a302d8f3a286f0314/who_were_kpmg.pdf Who were K, P, M & G?] * [http://www.kpmg.hu/index.thtml/hu/_ki/strollth/klynveld_pieter/index.html KPMG Hungary]
==References== <references/>
{{DEFAULTSORT:Klijnveld, Piet}} [[Category:1874 births]] [[Category:1945 deaths]] [[Category:Dutch accountants]] [[Category:Dutch businesspeople]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Amsterdam]] [[Category:KPMG people]]

{{about||the Wyoming Supreme Court judge|Ralph Kimball (judge)|the English cricketer|Ralph Kimbell}} {{BLP sources|date=March 2014}} {{notability|biographies|date=December 2015}} '''Ralph Kimball''' (born 1944) is an author on the subject of [[data warehousing]] and [[business intelligence]]. He is one of the original architects of [[data warehousing]] and is known for long-term convictions that data warehouses must be designed to be understandable and fast. His methodology, also known as [[dimensional modeling]] or the Kimball methodology, has become the de facto standard in the area of [[decision support]].
He is the principal author of the best-selling<ref name="2012-09-28_Informatica" /> books ''The Data Warehouse Toolkit'',<ref name="Whitehorn_2010-03-09_CW" /> ''The Data Warehouse Lifecycle Toolkit'', ''The Data Warehouse ETL Toolkit'' and ''The Kimball Group Reader'', published by Wiley and Sons.
==Career== After receiving a Ph.D.<ref name="2012-09-28_Informatica" /> in 1973 from [[Stanford University]] in electrical engineering (specializing in man-machine systems), Ralph joined the [[PARC (company)|Xerox Palo Alto Research Center]] (PARC). At PARC Ralph was a principal designer of the [[Xerox Star]] Workstation, the first commercial product to use mice, icons and windows.
Kimball then became vice president of applications at Metaphor Computer Systems, a [[decision support system|decision support software]] and services provider. He developed the Capsule Facility in 1982. The Capsule was a graphical programming technique which connected icons together in a logical flow, allowing a very visual style of programming for non-programmers. The Capsule was used to build reporting and analysis applications at Metaphor.
Kimball founded Red Brick Systems in 1986, serving as CEO until 1992. Red Brick Systems was acquired by Informix, which is now owned by [[IBM]].<ref name="2015-12-11_IBM" /> Red Brick was known for its [[relational database]] optimized for data warehousing. Their claim to fame was the use of bit-map [[Index (database)|Indexes]] in order to achieve performance gains that amounted to almost 10 times that of other Database vendors at that time.
Ralph Kimball Associates incorporated in 1992 to provide data warehouse consulting and education.
The Kimball Group, founded by Kimball,<ref name="2012-09-28_Informatica" /> formalized existing long-term relationships between Ralph Kimball Associates, DecisionWorks Consulting, and InfoDynamics LLC.
==Bibliography== * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |author2=Margy Ross |title=The Data Warehouse Toolkit: The Definitive Guide to Dimensional Modeling |edition=3rd|publisher=Wiley |year=2013 |isbn=978-1-118-53080-1 }} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |author2=Margy Ross |title=The Kimball Group Reader |publisher=Wiley |year=2010 |isbn=978-0-470-56310-6 }} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |author2=Margy Ross |author3=Warren Thornthwaite |author4=Joy Mundy |author5=Bob Becker |title=The Data Warehouse Lifecycle Toolkit |edition=2nd |publisher=Wiley |year=2008 |isbn=978-0-470-14977-5 }} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |author2=Joe Caserta |title=The Data Warehouse ETL Toolkit |publisher=Wiley |year=2004 |isbn=0-7645-6757-8 }} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball|first=Ralph |author2=Margy Ross |title=The Data Warehouse Toolkit: The Complete Guide to Dimensional Modeling |edition=2nd |publisher=Wiley |year=2002 |isbn=0-471-20024-7 }} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |author2=Richard Merz |title=The Data Webhouse Toolkit: Building the Web-Enabled Data Warehouse |publisher=Wiley |year=2000 |isbn=0-471-37680-9 }} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |title=The Data Warehouse Lifecycle Toolkit |publisher=Wiley |year=1998 |isbn=0-471-25547-5 |display-authors=etal}} * {{Cite book |last=Kimball |first=Ralph |title=The Data Warehouse Toolkit |publisher=Wiley |year=1996 |isbn=978-0-471-15337-5 }}
== References == {{Reflist|refs=
<ref name="2015-12-11_IBM">{{cite web |url = http://www.ibm.com/software/data/informix/redbrick/ |title = IBM Red Brick Warehouse |publisher = [[IBM]] |date = 2015-12-11 |accessdate = 2017-03-04 |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20151211202207/http://www-03.ibm.com/software/products/en/redbrick |archivedate = 2015-12-11 |quote = |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
<ref name="2012-09-28_Informatica">{{cite web |url = https://www.informatica.com/about-us/news/news-releases/2012/09/20120928-dr-ralph-kimball-and-informatica-host-big-data-best-practices-webinar.html |title = Dr. Ralph Kimball and Informatica Host Big Data Best Practices Webinar Industry Leaders and Innovators Share Newly Emerging Best Practices for Big Data |publisher = [[Informatica]] |date = 2012-09-28 |accessdate = 2015-12-11 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6dhhpaSNd?url=https://www.informatica.com/about-us/news/news-releases/2012/09/20120928-dr-ralph-kimball-and-informatica-host-big-data-best-practices-webinar.html |archivedate = 2015-12-11 |quote = Dr. Ralph Kimball, founder of the Kimball Group, is known worldwide as an innovator, writer, educator, speaker and consultant in the field of data warehousing. He has remained steadfast in his long-term conviction that data warehouses must be designed to be understandable and fast. Ralph's books on dimensional design techniques have become the all-time best sellers in data warehousing and he has trained more than 10,000 IT professionals around the globe. Prior to founding Kimball Group, he worked at Metaphor, founded Red Brick Systems and co-invented the Star workstation at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center (PARC). Ralph has his Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering from Stanford University. |deadurl = yes |df = }}</ref>
<ref name="Whitehorn_2010-03-09_CW">{{cite web | url = http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240016833/Inmon-vs-Kimball-data-warehousing-the-debate-over-DW-architecture | title = Inmon vs. Kimball data warehousing: the debate over DW architecture | last = Whitehorn | first = Mark | authorlink = | publisher = [[ComputerWeekly.com]] | date = 2010-03-09 | accessdate = 2015-12-11 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151003080126/http://www.computerweekly.com/news/2240016833/Inmon-vs-Kimball-data-warehousing-the-debate-over-DW-architecture | archivedate = 2015-10-03 | quote = Indeed, the fact that [[Bill Inmon|Inmon]] wrote a foreword for the first edition of Kimball’s book The Data Warehouse Toolkit tells us that they probably take a balanced view. }}</ref>
}}
==External links== * [http://www.kimballgroup.com/ Kimball Group] * [http://www.kimballgroup.com/2004/03/differences-of-opinion/ Differences of Opinion: The Kimball bus architecture and the Corporate Information Factory]
{{Data warehouse}}
